questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of severe diarrhea for the past three days. Diarrhea developed suddenly, is non-bloody, and has not been associated with abdominal pain. He has also experienced chronic symptoms of epigastric burning and an acid taste in the mouth, for which he recently started taking over-the-counter medication. The patient’s BMI is 32 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s current presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient has been having reflux symptoms (epigastric burning and acid taste in the mouth), for which he recently started taking an over-the-counter medication. Afterward, he started having severe watery diarrhea. Magnesium hydroxide is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms of the answer choices listed.  

Magnesium hydroxide is an antacid, a class of medication that neutralizes gastric acid and reduces acid delivery to the duodenum. Several antacids are available, including magnesium hydroxide, aluminum hydroxide, and calcium carbonate.    

Magnesium hydroxide is sold as chewable tablets, capsules, and liquid formulations with various added flavors. It is primarily used to alleviate constipation by acting as an osmotic laxative but can also relieve indigestion and heartburn. When taken orally, the osmotic force of the magnesia suspension draws fluids from the intracellular compartment and retains those already within the intestinal lumen. These changes distend the bowel, thus stimulating nerves within the colon wall, inducing peristalsis and diarrhea. Moreover, the medication can occasionally cause hypermagnesemia in patients with renal insufficiency.   

Option Analysis

❌ Aluminum hydroxide antacid:
Incorrect: Aluminum hydroxide is used as an antacid. It neutralizes the acidity of stomach content, which may relieve the symptoms of ulcers, heartburn, or dyspepsia. It can, however, cause constipation and is therefore often used with magnesium hydroxide or magnesium carbonate, which have counterbalancing laxative effects.  
❌ Histamine 2 receptor antagonists:
Incorrect: Histamine 2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) block the action of histamine at the H2 receptors of gastric parietal cells, thereby decreasing gastric acid production. Side effects are uncommon and include vitamin B12 deficiency, mental status changes, cardiotoxicity, and idiosyncratic myelosuppression. Gastrointestinal upset is rare.  
✅ Magnesium hydroxide antacid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prokinetic:
Incorrect: A prokinetic agent (e.g. metoclopramide) is a drug that enhances gastrointestinal motility by increasing the strength and frequency of intestinal contractions without disrupting their rhythm. Prokinetic agents can cause increased stool frequency but are not available over the counter and are not indicated for the management of reflux symptoms.  
❌ Sucralfate:
Incorrect: Sucralfate is a sulfated polysaccharide complexed with aluminum hydroxide. It prevents acute, chemically-induced mucosal damage and heals chronic ulcers. Side effects are uncommon and include aluminum-induced neurotoxicity, anemia, and hypophosphatemia. Gastrointestinal upset is atypical.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with one month of nausea, vomiting, and early satiety. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure, type II diabetes mellitus, schizophrenia, and a prior episode of tardive dyskinesia. Current medications include aripiprazole, carvedilol, lisinopril, metformin, and pioglitazone. On physical examination there are hypoactive bowel sounds and an abdominal succussion splash is present. There is no significant tenderness to abdominal palpation. Laboratory values include a prolactin of 120 ng/mL and hemoglobin A1c of 12%. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Domperidone is an anti-dopaminergic agent used for treating gastroparesis. These days, it has largely been replaced by metoclopramide. Domperidone can help symptoms related to gastroparesis by inhibiting dopaminergic pathways in the brain and promoting muscarinic receptor-mediated gastric emptying.      

Domperidone increases the risk for tardive dyskinesia, which is a movement disorder thought to arise from an imbalance of dopamine blockade and overactivation of D1 receptors. Concomitant use of antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol, aripiprazole) is a relative contraindication to domperidone therapy. A prior history of tardive dyskinesia is an absolute contraindication.      

Additional relative contraindications include hyperprolactinemia and prolonged QT intervals whereas mechanical bowel obstruction is another absolute contraindication.  

Option Analysis

❌ Erythromycin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of gastroparesis. Erythromycin has promotility properties that can be used to manage the symptoms of gastroparesis. There are no contraindications to the use of erythromycin in this patient. 
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine reduces nausea by antagonizing H1-receptors in the vestibular apparatus and is not helpful in managing the symptoms of gastroparesis. While they are not contraindicated in this patient, first-generation antihistamines should be used sparingly as they have many side effects.
❌ Empagliflozin:
Incorrect: This patient has no contraindication to SGLT-2 inhibitors and would probably benefit from one given his history of congestive heart failure and hypertension. Contraindications include frequent urinary tract infections as well as a history of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis or Fournier gangrene.
❌ Granisetron:
Incorrect: Granisetron, like ondansetron, is a 5-HT3 antagonist that works in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. While it does not help gastroparesis-related nausea very much, it is not contraindicated in this patient.
✅ Domperidone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man begins complaining of abdominal pain while recovering in the post-anesthesia care unit after undergoing surgical repair for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The procedure was complicated by blood loss and hypotension. The patient states the current pain is 6 out of 10 in severity. Past medical history is notable for atherosclerosis and peripheral vascular disease. The patient has a 35-pack-year smoking history. His temperature of 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure of 118/70 mmHg, and pulse of 78/min. Localized abdominal pain is elicited with light palpation over the area in question. The surgical site is dry and healing. Which of the following portions of the colon is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has localized abdominal pain after undergoing an aortic aneurysm repair that was complicated by hypotension and blood loss. The most likely cause of his symptom is colonic ischemia, which occurs when blood flow to the large intestines is reduced to a level that is inadequate for delivery of the oxygen and nutrients required for cellular metabolism.

The condition typically affects the elderly. Watershed regions of the colon, such as the splenic flexure and distal sigmoid colon, are most often affected. These areas are watershed regions, which are defined as the vascular territories covered only by the distal reaches of major arteries; their blood supply is therefore limited, making them more susceptible to ischemia. Causes of colonic ischemia include periods of hypotension (e.g. blood loss during surgery), atherosclerosis, diabetes, and embolism.    

Acute colonic ischemia causes moderate, crampy, left-sided abdominal pain, hematochezia, and diarrhea. In contrast, chronic colonic ischemia causes recurrent postprandial abdominal pain that is usually accompanied by bloody diarrhea and unintentional weight loss.

Abdominal radiographs or CT are often the first tests ordered in patients with suspected colonic ischemia. However, a lower GI endoscopy is needed to confirm the diagnosis, which would reveal edema, cyanosis and/or ulceration of the colonic mucosa.    

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ascending colon:
Incorrect: The ascending colon receives its blood supply from branches of the superior mesenteric artery. The ascending colon is not a watershed area. It is at low risk of ischemia secondary to hypoperfusion.  
❌ Hepatic flexure  :
Incorrect: The hepatic flexure receives blood supply from branches of the superior mesenteric artery. Since it is also not a watershed area, the hepatic flexure is at low risk of ischemia secondary to hypoperfusion.  
✅ Splenic flexure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Descending colon:
Incorrect: The descending colon is supplied by the inferior mesenteric artery. It is not a watershed region, and therefore, this portion of the colon is not at the high risk of ischemia in the event of hypoperfusion.  
❌ Rectum:
Incorrect: The rectum receives its blood supply from the superior, middle, and inferior rectal arteries. It is often the site of portosystemic anastomosis and varices. However, it is not a watershed region and therefore is not at high risk of ischemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of pain with defecation. The symptoms began 2 weeks ago. The pain is worse with straining, and the patient has occasionally noticed streaks of fresh blood on his stools. He works as a construction worker, and his diet consists mostly of fast food. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 142/85 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical exam shows multiple purplish-blue sacs in the anal canal. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for providing sensory innervation to the lesion site?
questions.solution:
Hemorrhoids arise from the cushions that line the rectum and anal canal, which are made of connective tissue, smooth muscle, and the blood-filled arteriovenous plexus. These blood vessels can become abnormally dilated and distended, causing them to become protruding masses. Abnormal distension of blood vessels typically occurs in cases of excessive straining (e.g., chronic constipation, chronic cough), prolonged sitting, and pregnancy.  

Hemorrhoids can be divided into internal and external hemorrhoids. Internal hemorrhoids are located above the pectinate line, which divides the upper two thirds and lower third of the anal canal. Internal hemorrhoids usually bleed, but they are not painful, since they receive visceral innervation from the parasympathetic pelvic splanchnic nerves and the sympathetic inferior mesenteric plexus.  

In contrast, external hemorrhoids are located below the pectinate line. They bleed less frequently, but they are painful and pruritic, because they receive somatic innervation from the inferior rectal branch of the pudendal nerve.  

Diagnosis of internal and external hemorrhoids can be made by visual inspection and digital rectal exam. Conservative management includes increased dietary intake of fiber, increased water intake, and stool softeners to prevent future constipation. Local anesthetics, such as lidocaine, can also be used. For internal hemorrhoids that persistently bleed, rubber band ligation can be done. External hemorrhoids can be treated by hemorrhoidectomy (surgical removal of hemorrhoids) if the condition is persistent or severe.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pelvic splanchnic nerves:
Incorrect: The pelvic splanchnic nerves provide parasympathetic innervation to areas above the pectinate line. However, this patient reports pain with defecation, which is more consistent with the presentation of external hemorrhoids. External hemorrhoids are below the pectinate line and therefore are not innervated by the pelvic splanchnic nerves.  
✅ Pudendal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior mesenteric plexus:
Incorrect: The inferior mesenteric plexus provides sympathetic innervation to areas above the pectinate line. However, this patient endorses pain with defecation. This is most consistent with the presentation of external hemorrhoids. External hemorrhoids are below the pectinate line and therefore are not innervated by the inferior mesenteric plexus.  
❌ Medial cluneal nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve innervates the portion of the buttocks that is closest to the midline of the body. However, it does not innervate the opening of the anal canal, which is where the patient’s external hemorrhoids are located.  
❌ Genitofemoral nerve:
Incorrect: The genitofemoral nerve innervates the upper anterior thighs, as well as the scrotum in men and mons pubis in women. This nerve does not relay sensory information from the anal canal.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is currently on postoperative day one after having an uncomplicated open appendectomy. The patient’s pain is well-controlled, but he has noticed diminished sensation and burning pain in the area just below the belly button. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's surgical incision appears to be healing well without extravasation of fluids on gentle palpation. The patient has diminished sensation suprapubically. Strength and sensation testing throughout the bilateral lower extremities is intact. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
This patient has paresthesias and diminished sensation in the suprapubic region on postoperative day one. These findings are most reflective of injury to the iliohypogastric nerve, likely due to a Lanz incision performed too far laterally or inferiorly.

Several superficial abdominal nerves are at increased risk of injury depending on the incision and surgery performed. Nerves at risk primarily include the inferior thoracic spinal nerves T7-T12, the iliohypogastric nerve, and the ilioinguinal nerve.

Specifically, any incision made too far lateral, inferior, or superior to the correct anatomic site may injure a thoracic spinal nerve, resulting in numbness and paresthesias at that level. For example, a  Kocher incision may injure the 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves.

Injury to the iliohypogastric or ilioinguinal nerves can arise from lower abdominal incisions. For example, a Pfannenstiel incision extended too far inferiorly or laterally may injure either nerve. Injury to the iliohypogastric nerve manifests with pain and paresthesias suprapubically, whereas injury to the ilioinguinal nerve manifests with these symptoms over the labia, scrotum, or thigh.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliohypogastric nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Femoral nerve:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve lies deep in the pelvis and is rarely injured during an open appendectomy. Injury to the femoral nerve would present with weakness in the quadriceps and iliopsoas muscles. In contrast, this patient has normal strength in the lower extremities.  
❌ Inferior epigastric artery  :
Incorrect: A pfannenstiel incision or a paracentesis performed too medially may result in injury to this artery. In addition, injury to the inferior epigastric artery would more likely result in hematoma formation, as opposed to diminished sensation in the suprapubic region.  
❌ T10 thoracic spinal nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to this nerve would manifest with paresthesias at the level of the umbilicus. In contrast, this patient has paresthesias in the region inferior to the umbilicus.  
❌ 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves  :
Incorrect: A right-sided Kocher incision extended too far laterally or inferiorly can injure the 7th and 8th thoracic spinal nerves. However, Kocher incisions are typically done for biliary procedures or splenectomies instead of appendectomies.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office to be evaluated for recurrent episodes of epigastric bloating and crampy pain. The pain usually begins after eating and is relieved by vomiting or lying on her stomach. The patient is a dancer and joined a training program a few months ago. She has lost 30-lbs (13.6 kg) over the past two months while on a “crash diet.” Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended and tender abdomen with high-pitched bowel sounds. A plain abdominal x-ray reveals findings suggestive of proximal small bowel obstruction. The upper gastrointestinal series demonstrates a marked delay in the passage of the contrast from the duodenum into the more distal small bowel. The delay resolves when the patient takes a knee-chest position. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of recurrent epigastric pain aggravated with food consumption and relieved with vomiting or lying prone, combined with the imaging findings, are consistent with superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome.   

The SMA typically leaves the aorta at an angle of 45 degrees. If the angle diminishes to an angle less than 22 degrees, the transverse portion of the duodenum can get entrapped between the SMA and aorta, leading to symptoms of partial bowel obstruction.    

Acute loss of mesenteric fat (e.g., recent weight loss, low body weight, severe burns, and prolonged bed rest) is thought to permit the artery to drop posteriorly, trapping the bowel and causing an intermittent obstruction. It can also occur in patients with pronounced lordosis or after surgical correction of scoliosis, as this procedure lengthens the spine resulting in decreased mobility of SMA.  

Patients often have epigastric bloating and crampy pain, particularly after eating that may be relieved with vomiting. The symptoms may resolve with the patient in the prone, left lateral decubitus, or a knee-chest position, which increases the angle between the SMA and the aorta. It may present acutely with signs and symptoms of small bowel obstruction or chronically with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, vague abdominal symptoms, and early satiety. Physical examination may show abdominal distension, a succussion splash, and high-pitched bowel sounds. The diagnosis is established based on clinical features and noninvasive imaging that demonstrates an abnormal angle between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transmural inflammation of the intestine:
Incorrect: Transmural inflammation of the intestine is seen in Crohn disease. Patients typically present with chronic right lower quadrant pain (not epigastric pain) and other constitutional symptoms. Moreover, the delayed passage of contrast via the duodenum suggests duodenal compression.  
❌ Intermittent increase of intra-gallbladder pressure:
Incorrect: Biliary colic occurs as the gallbladder contracts against an obstructing stone, leading to an intermittent increase of intra-gallbladder pressure. The pain is typically episodic and is located in the right upper quadrant.   
❌ Progressive pancreatic inflammation:
Incorrect: Pain accompanied by malabsorption may be due to chronic pancreatitis. It is, however, an unlikely diagnosis in the absence of risk factors (e.g. heavy alcohol use). An abdominal x-ray may show pancreatic calcification.  
✅ Duodenal compression between arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves:
Incorrect: Selective hypersensitization of visceral afferent nerves is thought to be the underlying cause of irritable bowel syndrome. Weight loss and recurrent epigastric pain with bloating relieved with vomiting in this patient suggest an alternative underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal distension. The patient has had abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite associated with progressive abdominal distension for the past three days. His last bowel movement was five days ago. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient had an open cholecystectomy several years ago. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen with diffuse tenderness to palpation, but no rigidity, rebound tenderness, or guarding. A supine abdominal x-ray is shown below. Which pathophysiological process most likely contributed to this patient’s condition?  



Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane
Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery
Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus
Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine
Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall

questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation is typical of intestinal obstruction (e.g., abdominal distention, abdominal pain, nausea, and constipation). This, together with a history of chronic constipation, is suggestive of sigmoid volvulus.   

Sigmoid volvulus occurs when an air-filled loop of the sigmoid colon twists about its mesentery, forming a closed-loop obstruction. The symptoms of volvulus are those of acute bowel obstruction. Patients present with progressive abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting (secondary to continuous gas production by the intraluminal bacteria). This can rapidly progress to generalized abdominal pain and tenderness.    

Factors that can precipitate the development of sigmoid volvulus include: 
  •  Long redundant sigmoid colon with a narrow mesenteric attachment 
  •  Chronic constipation 
  •  Hirschsprung disease 
  •  Colonic hypomotility (e.g., neurogenic bowel in neurogenic diseases and diabetic enteropathy) 
  Sigmoid volvulus produces a characteristic bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance, with the convexity of the loop lying in the right upper quadrant (opposite the site of obstruction) on plain abdominal x-ray. The coffee bean appearance of the colon is created when the sigmoid colon distends with gas and the medial walls of the dilated bowel loop oppose one another and form the cleft of the coffee bean or an inverted U shape.  



Option Analysis

❌ Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane:
Incorrect: Sliding hiatal hernias occur due to the laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane leading to the herniation of the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach into the thoracic cavity. Patients usually present with reflux symptoms (e.g., heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of intestinal obstruction.  
✅ Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus:
Incorrect: Paralytic ileus results when there is a nonmechanical decrease in flow of intestinal contents. It can lead to intestinal obstruction which is seen on abdominal x-ray as generalized distension of small and large bowel. A coffee-bean sign as seen on this patient’s plain radiograph suggests sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine:
Incorrect: Intussusception (telescoping of the proximal intestine into the distal intestine) can cause intermittent, colicky abdominal pain and currant jelly stools. It typically occurs in infants aged 6-36 months. Plain abdominal radiographs may show a “target sign”, not the coffee bean sign seen in this patient.  
❌ Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis (inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall) can present with left lower quadrant pain. It usually does not cause mechanical intestinal obstruction or a coffee bean sign on x-ray.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain. Three months ago, the patient underwent uncomplicated abdominal surgery to resect a large uterine fibroid. Past surgical history is notable for a C-section and cholecystectomy. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, high pitched bowel sounds are heard on auscultation and there is guarding and diffuse abdominal tenderness with palpation. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows dilated loops of the small bowel with a transition point. What is the cause of this patient’s current disorder?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain, guarding, and pain with palpation in the setting of a history of multiple abdominal surgeries. Furthermore, physical examination reveals high-pitched bowel sounds, and CT imaging demonstrates dilated bowel loops with a transition point. In combination, these findings indicate a small bowel obstruction (SBO).    

While SBO can be caused by several factors, such as a space-occupying malignancy, infection, trauma, or irradiation, the vast majority are caused by peritoneal adhesions. Peritoneal adhesions form in 93 to 100% of patients following abdominal surgery. Adhesions are fibrous connective tissue bands analogous to scar tissue on the skin that form between two or more intra-abdominal organs and/or the inner abdominal wall. These adhesions can cause a lattice of dense connective tissue throughout the abdominal cavity, making future surgical operations difficult. The adhesions can lead to strangulation of small bowel loops and SBO. They can lead to other complications including female infertility and chronic abdominal pain.  

Option Analysis

❌ Malignancy:
Incorrect: Malignancies can cause small bowel obstruction. However, given this patient’s history of multiple abdominal surgeries, peritoneal adhesions are more likely the cause of SBO in this patient.  
❌ Paralytic ileus:
Incorrect: Paralytic ileus occurs in the days following an abdominal operation. In contrast, this patient is several months out from her most recent abdominal surgery.  
✅ Peritoneal adhesions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uterine lLeiomyomata :
Incorrect: Large uterine fibroids can potentially cause bowel obstruction, and while this patient has a history of uterine leiomyomata or fibroids, the mass was resected 3 months ago. Recurrence of uterine fibroids after surgery can occur within the first few years after removal, but they do not typically recur within months after surgery.  
❌ Abscess from previous surgery:
Incorrect: While an intra-abdominal abscess can lead to SBO, it  would present with an air-fluid level on imaging as well as systemic signs such as fever, nausea, and vomiting. Most intra-abdominal abscesses occur within 1-3 weeks of surgery. It is rare for them to develop several months after surgery.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man undergoes a surgical repair for a large abdominal aortic aneurysm. His surgery was complicated by hypotension, immediately managed with intravenous fluids. A few hours postoperatively, the patient complains of abdominal pain, followed by an episode of bloody diarrhea. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen with no significant tenderness or guarding and normal bowel sounds. Laboratory evaluation reveals metabolic acidosis and a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. Which of the following areas will most likely show abnormal findings on a CT scan?
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain followed by an episode of bloody diarrhea most likely has nonocclusive ischemic colitis, secondary to repairing the abdominal aortic aneurysm which resulted in an episode of hypotension. Ischemic injury to the colon usually occurs due to a sudden and transient reduction in blood flow, resulting in a low-flow state and most commonly affects the watershed areas.   

Watershed areas refer to body regions that receive dual blood supply from the most distal branches of two large arteries. In the intestine, these include the splenic flexure at the area between the territory of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) and the rectosigmoid junction at the area between the sigmoid artery (IMA) and the superior rectal artery.   

Patients with ischemic colitis usually present with crampy abdominal pain, followed by hematochezia or bloody diarrhea. Physical examination often reveals abdominal tenderness of variable severity over the location of the affected portion of the bowel. A CT scan with intravenous contrast may show a thickened bowel wall. Colonoscopy confirms the diagnosis and shows pale mucosa with petechial bleeding, bluish hemorrhagic nodules, and cyanotic mucosa with hemorrhage.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hepatic flexure:
Incorrect: The hepatic flexure is the sharp bend between the ascending colon and the transverse colon and lies in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It receives blood supply from the SMA and is unlikely to undergo ischemia secondary to hypotension.  
✅ Splenic flexure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rectum:
Incorrect: Ischemia is less common in the rectum as it receives collateral blood supply via rectal arteries.  
❌ Ascending colon:
Incorrect: Ascending colon is supplied by branches of the superior mesenteric artery and is less commonly affected by hypotension.  
❌ Mid-transverse colon:
Incorrect: Mid-transverse colon is supplied by branches of the superior mesenteric artery and is less commonly affected by hypotension.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because he noticed rectal bleeding. He has occasionally noticed a few streaks of bright-red blood on the toilet paper after wiping, but today he saw blood dripping in the toilet at the end of defecation. The patient also reports mild itching around the perianal opening but no pain. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination the abdomen is nontender and nondistended. The digital rectal examination does not demonstrate an abnormal mass or tenderness. Anoscopy is significant for bulging purplish-blue veins above the dentate line. Which of the following best describes the cutaneous innervation of this region above the dentate line?

choices.text: This region is not innervated by a cutaneous nerve.

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with painless rectal bleeding and bulging purplish-blue veins above the dentate line is consistent with internal hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that can cause discomfort and bleeding. They can be classified based on their location relative to the dentate line.  

Internal hemorrhoids are subepithelial vascular cushions consisting of connective tissue, smooth muscle fibers, and arteriovenous communications between terminal branches of the superior rectal artery and rectal veins and are located proximal to the dentate line. They have autonomic innervation from the inferior hypogastric plexus (sensitive to stretch only) and are devoid of cutaneous innervation. Internal hemorrhoids may prolapse or bleed but rarely become painful unless they develop thrombosis and necrosis.  

External hemorrhoids arise from the inferior hemorrhoidal veins located below the dentate line. They are covered with the squamous epithelium of the anal canal, and have cutaneous innervation from the inferior rectal nerve, a branch of the pudendal nerve.  



Option Analysis

❌ Pudendal nerve:
Incorrect: External hemorrhoids originate below the dentate line, are covered by squamous epithelium, and have cutaneous innervation by the pudendal nerve. This patient with bulging veins above the dentate line most likely has an internal hemorrhoid.  
❌ Ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: Ilioinguinal nerve is a sensory nerve that carries sensations from the upper and medial part of the thigh, the root of the penis, and the upper part of the scrotum in the males and mons pubis and labia majora in the females. It does not innervate the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Inferior gluteal nerve:
Incorrect: The inferior gluteal nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the gluteus maximus muscle.   
✅ This region is not innervated by a cutaneous nerve. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic splanchnic nerves:
Incorrect: Splanchnic nerves (S2-S4) provide parasympathetic (not cutaneous) innervation to the pelvic and genital organs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and nausea for the past several hours. The patient vomited once and saw a small amount of blood in the vomitus. His past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient has not experienced similar symptoms before. He is not prescribed any medications, but he routinely takes multiple ibuprofen tablets for headaches. He took several tablets for a severe headache this morning that would “not go away.” He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and does not consume alcohol or other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness with no guarding. A complete blood count shows a hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy shows a deep, bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb. Bleeding from which of the following arteries is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (abdominal discomfort, nausea, and hematemesis) in combination with endoscopic findings of a bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb, is consistent with the erosion of the ulcer into the gastroduodenal artery, which perfuses both pylorus and the proximal part of the duodenum. Risk factors for bleeding duodenal ulcers include Helicobacter pylori infection, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use, and smoking.  

Posterior duodenal wall ulcers are more prone to bleeding than anterior duodenal ulcers due to the posterior relationship of the gastroduodenal artery. In contrast, anterior duodenal ulcers involve the anterior wall, and are prone to perforation but not bleeding. Duodenal ulcers are more likely to bleed than are gastric ulcers.  

Gastric ulcers commonly involve the lesser curvature of the stomach at the junction of the body and antrum. The left and right gastric arteries run along the lesser curvature of the stomach and can bleed from gastric ulcers. The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, passes posterior to the stomach (separated by the pancreas), and is rarely eroded by posterior gastric ulcers.  



Option Analysis

❌ Splenic artery:
Incorrect: The splenic artery arises from the celiac trunk, passes posterior to the stomach (separated by the pancreas) and is rarely involved in bleeding posterior gastric ulcers. Posterior duodenal wall ulcers with bleeding do not involve the splenic artery.  
✅ Gastroduodenal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding from a gastric ulcer. However, a posterior duodenal wall ulcer is not likely to involve the left gastric artery.  
❌ Right gastric artery:
Incorrect: The right gastric artery runs along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is at risk of bleeding secondary to gastric ulcers. However, a posterior duodenal wall ulcer is not likely to involve the right gastric artery.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left and right gastroepiploic arteries run along the greater curvature of the stomach. They will not bleed with posterior duodenal wall ulcerations.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of recurrent bloating and diarrhea. The symptoms began 2 months ago. During this time, she has had bulky and foul-smelling stools with no visible blood as well as an unintentional 9-lb weight loss. In addition, the patient has had a pruritic rash on her arms, which she attributes to “sensitive skin.” Past medical history is notable for vitiligo and hypothyroidism, which is well controlled with levothyroxine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Large patches of hypopigmentation are seen. There are multiple tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the patient’s elbows and dorsal forearms bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient’s gastrointestinal tract is likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Atrophic mucosa with loss of villi and crypt hyperplasia
Periodic-acid Schiff positive macrophages in the small intestine mucosa
Breakdown of intestinal crypt epithelium with infiltration of neutrophils
Nodular collections of macrophages and giant cells in the intestinal epithelium

questions.solution:
This adolescent female is presenting with signs and symptoms of celiac disease, such steatorrhea, weight loss, and dermatitis herpetiformis. Furthermore, patients with celiac disease are predisposed to various autoimmune conditions, which may explain her previously diagnosed vitiligo and hypothyroidism.

 Endoscopy with subsequent biopsy of the small intestine is essential for the diagnosis of celiac disease. It would likely demonstrate villous atrophy (black arrow) and crypt hyperplasia or elongation (yellow arrow). These findings occur since in patients with celiac disease or chronic inflammation, there is increased apoptosis of intestinal cells. In an attempt to replace the lost cells, the number of regenerative cells within the crypts of the small intestines increases, leading to crypt hyperplasia. Over time, there is an inability to keep up with the constant apoptosis, and villous atrophy ensues.  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Atrophic mucosa with loss of villi and crypt hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Periodic-acid Schiff positive macrophages in the small intestine mucosa:
Incorrect: Patients with Whipple disease will have periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages in the small intestine mucosa. The condition is caused by infection with the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It most commonly presents in males between 30-60 years of age. Although Whipple disease can cause diarrhea and abdominal pain, it also tends to manifest with arthritis and cardiac symptoms (e.g. vascular insufficiency).
❌ Normal intestinal architecture:
Incorrect: Normal intestinal architecture can be seen in patients with lactose intolerance. Lactose intolerance may present with symptoms similar to those of celiac disease, such as bloating and diarrhea. However, this patient’s weight loss, dermatitis herpetiformis, and history of other autoimmune conditions (e.g., vitiligo, hypothyroidism) would not be explained by lactose intolerance alone. 
❌ Breakdown of intestinal crypt epithelium with infiltration of neutrophils:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis (UC) occurs due to dysregulation of the colonic epithelium. The abnormal epithelium is more permeable to intestinal bacteria, which subsequently activate immune cells such as macrophages, neutrophils, and T-cells. Crypt abscesses (infiltration of neutrophils) are characteristic of UC. However, UC commonly presents with bloody diarrhea and would not account for this patient’s symptoms.
❌ Nodular collections of macrophages and giant cells in the intestinal epithelium:
Incorrect: Crohn disease is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are composed of macrophages and giant cells, in the intestinal wall. Crohn disease presents with non-contiguous lesions and therefore results in nodular collections at various points throughout the digestive system. Although Crohn disease may result in chronic diarrhea, it would not adequately explain this patient’s cutaneous findings.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the office with complaints of intermittent abdominal cramps and diarrhea for the past 2 months. He has had 4-5 bowel movements per day containing small-volume stools that are mixed with blood and mucus. Review of systems reveals a 5.9-kg (13-lbs) weight loss, fatigue, and loss of appetite. He also experiences pain and tenderness in the right knee that responds to indomethacin. The remainder of the history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness in the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Laboratory results are as follows:


 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9.7 mg/dL 
 Platelets  290,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes  13,200/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  120 mm/hr 
 
Colonoscopy shows erythematous and edematous bowel wall mucosa extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon with small shallow ulcers throughout the involved region. Biopsy of the involved tissue sample will most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa
Pseudomembranes of fibrin and inflammatory debris

questions.solution:
This patient has constitutional symptoms (fatigue, weight loss, loss of appetite), chronic bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. Laboratory findings of anemia, increased ESR and leukocytosis, together with colonoscopy findings of continuous inflammation and ulceration in the rectum and sigmoid colon, are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).  UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation of the rectum that may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve other parts of the colon. Clinically, the condition presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.  Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Microscopic features suggestive of ulcerative colitis include:  
  •  Mucosal and submucosal inflammation (Figure A): Due to diffuse, chronic infiltrates in the mucosa and lamina propria. 
  •  Crypt abscess (Figure B): Clusters of neutrophils and pus within crypt epithelium. 
  •  Formation of pseudopolyps (Figure C): When the ulceration destroys significant portions of the mucosa, the residual mucosa protrudes above the surface of the ulcers in the form of polyps. Since these are not true neoplastic polyps, they are called pseudopolyps. 
  •  Basal lymphoid aggregates (Figure A): Prominent lymphoid aggregates located at the border of the submucosa. 
  •  Paneth cell metaplasia (arrows in Figure D): Occurs exclusively in affected mucosa and is a useful marker of IBD.


Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Figure B (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Figure C (Retrieved from: flickr.com



Figure D (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)

Option Analysis

❌ Caseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Caseating granulomas are aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with central necrosis that are usually seen on histopathology of intestinal tuberculosis. Although chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea are the presenting symptoms, a history of travel to an endemic area or exposure to infected individuals is usually present.
✅ Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thickening of the muscularis mucosae:
Incorrect: Thickening (hypertrophy) of the muscularis mucosae causes stricture formation which narrows the intestinal lumen. It is a complication of long-standing Crohn disease, diverticulitis, or malignancy. It is not seen in patients with ulcerative colitis.
❌ Pseudomembranes of fibrin and inflammatory debris:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranes of fibrin and inflammatory debris are seen in C. difficile infection that clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. This infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g.,clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins). Toxic megacolon is a potential complication. Bloody diarrhea is unlikely.
❌ Distended macrophages in lamina propria:
Incorrect: Distended macrophages in the lamina propria are pathognomonic of Whipple disease. The condition is a multisystem progressive disease presenting with joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, and central nervous system involvement. Endoscopy usually shows a normal appearing mucosa.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. She does not have any abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Past medical history is noncontributory. There is no family history of cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, and a 5-mm polyp is found in the rectosigmoid colon. The polyp is biopsied, and subsequent microscopic analysis is performed. Histology shows non-dysplastic epithelial proliferation with serrations only at the epithelial surface and cellular proliferation confined to the lower portion of the crypts. It is determined that the polyp has minimal malignant potential. Which of the following best describes the histological subtype of this polyp?
questions.solution:
Colonic hyperplastic polyps are the most common epithelial proliferations seen on colonoscopy. They are usually located in the rectosigmoid region. The formation of these lesions is not completely understood, but they are thought to be the result of decreased epithelial cell turnover and delayed shedding of surface epithelial cells, which leads to a “pileup” of goblet cells. This excess of goblet cells ultimately causes the hyperproliferation seen in the basal portion of the crypts, while the luminal surface has a superficial serrated architecture. An image of a hyperplastic polyp is shown below.  

Although hyperplastic polyps have little malignant potential, it is important to distinguish them from serrated polyps, which are histologically similar and have malignant potential. The most useful histologic feature that distinguishes serrated polyps from hyperplastic polyps is the presence of serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands, including the crypt base. In contrast, hyperplastic polyps demonstrate serrated architecture confined to the epithelial surface.

Image reproduced from Flickr



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperplastic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serrated:
Incorrect: Although hyperplastic polyps and sessile serrated polyps are similar on microscopy, it is important to note that in serrated polyps, there is the presence of serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands, including the crypt base. This patient’s polyp demonstrates serration only at the epithelial surface. Furthermore, the polyp was determined to have minimal neoplastic potential, whereas serrated polyps have a high risk of progressing to cancer. 
❌ Adenomatous:
Incorrect: The three types of adenomatous polyps are villous, tubular, and tubulovillous. This patient’s polyp, which showed serration confined to the epithelial surface as well as cellular proliferation in crypts, is suggestive of a different subtype. Additionally, adenomatous polyps have significant malignant potential, whereas this patient's polyp has only minimal potential. 
❌ Hamartomatous:
Incorrect: Hamartomatous polyps are made up of tissue elements that are normally found at that site but are growing in a disorganized mass. Histological analysis of this patient’s polyp is more consistent with a different subtype. 
❌ Inflammatory pseudopolyp:
Incorrect: Inflammatory pseudopolyps are non-neoplastic projections of mucosa consisting of stromal and epithelial components as well as inflammatory cells. These polyps are commonly seen in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease. However, the histological characteristics of this patient’s polyp are more consistent with those of a hyperplastic polyp.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. He does not have any abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has no family history of cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, which reveals a few polyps in the colon. The polyps are biopsied and examined for abnormal histology. Which of the following histological subtypes is at the highest risk for malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Colonic polyps are abnormal colonic mucosal overgrowths and become increasingly common with age. Therefore, screening for colorectal cancer is recommended in asymptomatic individuals aged 45 and over. The preferred screening tool is a colonoscopy, which allows for direct visualization, biopsy, and removal of polyps.  

Colorectal polyps are subdivided into non-neoplastic polyps and neoplastic polyps. Non-neoplastic polyps include hamartomatous polyps, hyperplastic polyps, inflammatory pseudopolyps, mucosal polyps, and submucosal polyps. Neoplastic polyps include adenomatous polyps and serrated polyps. Adenomatous polyps are the most common and clinically important neoplastic polyps, since they give rise to a majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Adenomatous polyps can further be characterized based on their histological architecture (e.g., tubular, tubulovillous, villous). Villous polyps have the highest malignant potential, tubulovillous polyps have intermediate potential, and tubular polyps have the least malignant potential. In addition, polyps that are larger in size have a greater chance of malignant transformation.


Option Analysis

✅ Tubulovillous adenomatous:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hamartomatous:
Incorrect: Hamartomatous polyps are made up of tissue elements that are normally found at that site but are growing in a disorganized mass. Although they have mild malignant potential, another subtype is at greater risk of transformation.
❌ Hyperplastic:
Incorrect: Hyperplastic polyps are the most prevalent non-neoplastic polyps in the colon. Small hyperplastic polyps rarely, if ever, develop into colorectal cancers.
❌ Inflammatory pseudopolyp:
Incorrect: Inflammatory polyps are non-neoplastic projections of mucosa consisting of stromal and epithelial components as well as inflammatory cells. This finding is commonly seen in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis). Inflammatory polyps do not undergo neoplastic transformation.
❌ Mucosal:
Incorrect: Mucosal polyps, which are clinically insignificant, are usually small, less than 5 mm, and look similar to surrounding normal mucosa. They do not undergo neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because of perianal discomfort and foul-smelling discharge around the anus for the past 2 months. She also reports intermittent abdominal pain and watery diarrhea for the last few years for which she did not seek medical attention. She has no other significant past medical history and has not traveled outside of the country recently. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows canker sores on the oral mucosa. There is mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant of abdomen and an anterolateral anal fistula draining foul-smelling purulent discharge. Stool microscopy shows 1-2 cell/hpf leukocytes. Colonoscopy shows skip lesions and cobblestone appearance of the descending colon with rectal sparing. Which of the following findings will be seen on light microscopy of the involved tissue sample?

choices.text: Infiltration of lamina propria with atypical lymphocytes
Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes and atrophy of villi

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a perianal fistula (perianal discomfort, foul-smelling perianal discharge), a chronic history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain, and physical examination findings of aphthous ulcers (canker sores) and abdominal tenderness; she is most likely suffering from Crohn disease (CD).

CD is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it presents with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Systemic findings of inflammation (low-grade fever, weight loss, anemia, fatigue) can be seen. Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Microscopic features suggestive of CD include:

  •  Non-caseating granulomas (Figure A): Aggregates of epithelioid macrophages that may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a band of lymphocytes. 
  •  Crypt abscess (Figure B): Clusters of neutrophils and pus within crypt epithelium. 
  •  Transmural inflammation (Figure C): inflammation involving the entire thickness of intestinal wall. 
  •  Paneth cell metaplasia (arrows in Figure D): Occurs exclusively in affected mucosa and is a useful marker of IBD. 
  • Pseudopolyps (Figure E): When the ulceration destroys significant portions of the mucosa, the residual mucosa protrudes above the surface of the ulcers in the form of polyps. Since these are not true neoplastic polyps, they are called pseudopolyps.


Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)



Figure B (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)



Figure C (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure D (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure E (Reproduced from: flickr.com)

Complications other than perianal fistula formation include malabsorption (due to associated ileitis), as well as abscess or stricture formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Non-caseating granulomas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Caseating granulomas are aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with central necrosis that are usually seen on histopathology of patients with intestinal tuberculosis. Although chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea are the presenting symptoms, a history of travel to an endemic area or exposure to infected individuals is usually present. Cobblestoning of mucosa is also atypical.
❌ Infiltration of lamina propria with atypical lymphocytes:
Incorrect: Infiltration of lamina propria with atypical lymphocytes is characteristic of lymphomas arising in mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT or MALTomas). They usually arise in the stomach and present with dyspepsia and epigastric discomfort. Long-standing watery diarrhea and perianal fistula are atypical.
❌ Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes and atrophy of villi:
Incorrect: Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes and atrophy of villi is characteristic of celiac disease, which usually presents with foul-smelling bulky diarrhea and flatulence. It is usually associated with dietary gluten intake. Endoscopy shows atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum. Colon involvement is atypical.
❌ Distended macrophages in lamina propria:
Incorrect: Distended macrophages in the lamina propria are pathognomonic of Whipple disease. The condition is a multisystem progressive disease presenting with joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, and central nervous system involvement. Endoscopy usually shows a normal appearing mucosa. Perianal involvement is uncommon.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent because of abnormal pigmentation on his face. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and has been developing normally. The patient’s biological mother developed breast cancer at the age of 41. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several blue-gray to brown spots in the perioral region, as shown in the image below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

A genetic condition is suspected, and the patient undergoes a surveillance colonoscopy, which reveals numerous polyps in the small intestine and colon. Which of the following best describes the histological characteristics of the polyps seen on colonoscopy?

choices.text: Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle lined by normal intestinal epithelium
Serrated epithelial surface with proliferation of the basal portion of the crypts
Polypoid mass of inflamed and reactive mucosal tissue
Serrated luminal structure with mild dysplasia
Finger-like projections lined by dysplastic epithelium

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation and a family history of cancer, likely has Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS). Patients with PJS are predisposed to developing multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps. Although these polyps are most commonly benign, they may grow progressively and become symptomatic or undergo malignant transformation.    

Hamartomas are disorganized, tumorlike growths composed of mature cell types normally present at the site at which the polyp develops. Polyps in PJS most commonly develop in the small intestine, although they can also present in the stomach and colon. On gross evaluation, the polyps are large and pedunculated. Histologic examination will reveal a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.  


Option Analysis

✅ Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle lined by normal intestinal epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Serrated epithelial surface with proliferation of the basal portion of the crypts:
Incorrect: Hyperplastic polyps are the most common non-neoplastic polyps in the colon. The serrated surface contour can look similar to sessile serrated adenomas, and therefore they need to be differentiated due to the malignant potential of the latter. This patient with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, however, is predisposed to a different type of colonic polyp.
❌ Polypoid mass of inflamed and reactive mucosal tissue:
Incorrect: Inflammatory pseudopolyps are irregularly shaped patches of colonic mucosa that are the result of recurrent mucosal ulceration and regeneration. This type of polyp is typically seen in patients with localized or diffuse inflammation, such as in the case of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This patient lacks the features of IBD, however, making this type of colonic polyp unlikely.
❌ Serrated luminal structure with mild dysplasia:
Incorrect: Serrated polyps are often flat or sessile and are characterized by a saw-tooth appearance on histology. These polyps are often neoplastic with mild degrees of dysplasia. This patient with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, however, is predisposed to a different type of colonic polyp.
❌ Finger-like projections lined by dysplastic epithelium :
Incorrect: This histological description describes a villous adenoma, which has a very high likelihood of undergoing malignant transformation. This patient with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, however, is predisposed to the formation of a different type of colonic polyp.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his physician for a routine colonoscopy. A sample image from this procedure is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

No other abnormalities are seen. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Diverticulosis refers to outpouchings that form in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon. The exact pathogenic mechanism for diverticula formation is unknown, but one theory is that diverticula form in response to increased intracolonic pressure generated when the colon is processing smaller, non–fiber-containing stools. This increased pressure eventually pushes out part of the colon, forming sac-like appendages at the weakest segments, in the points where the colon is fed by blood vessels called the vasa recta. The most significant risk factors for the development of diverticulosis include diets low in fiber, high in red meat and fat, obesity, physical inactivity, and smoking.  



Most cases of diverticulosis are asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally as in this vignette. When symptomatic, they classically cause chronic nonspecific abdominal complaints, including bloating, crampy pain, excessive gas, and a change in bowel habits. Patients may also develop hematochezia. Sometimes, diverticula can become infected, causing diverticulitis, and patients may require oral or intravenous antibiotics depending on the severity of infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Low dietary fiber intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-gliadin antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-gliadin antibodies are more commonly associated with celiac disease. On endoscopy, patients with celiac disease will typically have normal appearing mucosa. Pathologic biopsy will demonstrate scalloping of the small bowel folds.  
❌ Coronary artery disease  :
Incorrect: Coronary artery disease is a risk factor for atherosclerosis of mesenteric vasculature, resulting in mesenteric ischemia. Patients with mesenteric ischemia will tend to have an area of colon that is pale, necrotic, or appears to have recently bled.  
❌ Mutation of the APC gene:
Incorrect: Mutation of the APC gene is associated with the condition familial adenomatous polyposis, which results in the early formation of precancerous polyps. The image above demonstrates diverticular disease, not precancerous polyps.  
❌ HLA-B27 mutation:
Incorrect: Mutations in HLA-B27 are associated with an increased risk of ankylosing spondylitis and ulcerative colitis. The lesions of ulcerative colitis are typically described as erythematous and friable  mucosa with superficial ulceration, with near universal involvement of the rectum.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of a positive fecal occult blood test during routine colorectal cancer screening. The patient has not experienced fatigue, changes in bowel habit, or recent weight loss. His medical and family history are noncontributory. His temperature is 36.2°C (97.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 14 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume of 80 μm3. Colonoscopy demonstrates two polyps in the sigmoid colon, which are then biopsied. Histological images of the polyps are shown below:  

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following gene mutations is responsible for the conversion of normal colon to the lesion found in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a positive fecal occult blood test (FOBT) and subsequently undergoes colonoscopy with biopsy. The biopsy results show a villous adenomatous polyp, which is a premalignant lesion. Clinically, adenomatous polyps are usually asymptomatic, but some may cause occult bleeding, secretory diarrhea, or partial intestinal obstruction.  

Adenomatous polyps can be classified into three categories: villous, tubulovillous, and tubular. Amongst them, villous polyps have the highest malignant potential. The transformation from normal epithelium to adenomatous polyp, and later carcinoma, is termed the adenoma-carcinoma sequence. It is characterized by a series of mutations:  

1) Normal mucosa to colon-at-risk: A change from normal mucosa to an at-risk colon occurs by acquiring a mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 5. Loss of the APC gene leads to accumulation of the β-catenin protein (transcription factor), which leads to constitutive transcription and unregulated cell proliferation.    

2) Colon-at-risk to adenomatous polyps: The KRAS proto-oncogene normally encodes for proteins that regulate cell-signal transduction. Mutations in KRAS lead to the formation of stabilized forms of these proteins, which makes them resistant to degradation. The presence of these stabilized proteins leads to constant transmission of extracellular growth signals.    

3) Adenomatous polyps to colorectal cancer: This final step is believed to be caused by a loss of tumor suppressor genes, such as TP53 and DCC, which are normally responsible for negatively regulating the cell cycle.  

Option Analysis

❌ TP53:
Incorrect: TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene and often referred to as "guardian of the genome". It is responsible for the production of DNA-binding protein p53. Once activated, p53 induces the transcription of p21, which blocks cyclin dependent kinases and thus cell cycle progression. TP53 mutations are responsible for most human cancers. However, TP53 leads to the progression of adenoma to carcinoma, not from normal colon to adenoma.  
❌ PTEN:
Incorrect: The phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) gene is a negative regulator of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway. Loss of function of this gene contributes to the development of breast, prostate, and endometrial cancer.  
❌ BRCA2:
Incorrect: BRCA2 is a tumor suppressor gene involved with DNA repair. It is associated with breast, ovarian, and pancreatic cancer. However, it is not involved in the pathogenesis of colorectal adenomas or cancer. 
❌ TSC1:
Incorrect: The tuberous sclerosis complex 1 (TSC1) is responsible for the production of hamartin protein, which is widely expressed in normal tissues. Inactivating mutations or complete loss of the TSC genes can give rise to tuberous sclerosis. 
✅ KRAS:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ MYCL1:
Incorrect: The MYCL1 gene encodes for a transcription factor. Its mutation is associated with certain lung cancers, not colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of intermittent constipation. The symptoms began several months ago. She often needs to strain during defecation and has occasionally noticed blood in her stool. The patient has no significant past medical history, but she states her father developed pancreatic cancer at a young age. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple, small, hyperpigmented macules on the buccal mucosa. Colonoscopy is performed and shows numerous polyps, with subsequent biopsy revealing hamartomatous mucosal polyps. This patient's diagnosis is most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with buccal mucosa hyperpigmentation and colonoscopy showing multiple hamartomatous polyps. She most likely has Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS), which also predisposes patients to developing breast cancer.   

PJS is an autosomal dominant condition that arises due to mutations in the STK11 gene. This gene encodes a tumor suppressor protein that is involved in cell signaling and apoptosis. Elimination of STK11 kinase activity is associated with a loss of growth suppression function, which likely contributes to the increased risk of malignancies in these patients.  

Mucocutaneous pigmented lesions are seen in 95% of patients and may be the first clue to underlying PJS. Lesions tend to arise in infancy, occurring around the mouth, perianal area, fingers, and toes. Many of these lesions fade after puberty, but those in the buccal mucosa tend to persist. Additionally, patients with PJS are predisposed to developing multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps. Although these polyps are most commonly benign, they may grow progressively and become symptomatic (e.g., intussusception, luminal occlusion causing constipation, anemia from chronic bleeding).    

The most clinically important manifestation of PJS is the increased risk for developing several gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies. The most common sites of gastrointestinal tract malignancy are the colon and pancreas, whereas the most common site of extraintestinal tract cancer is the breast.  

Option Analysis

✅ Breast cancer:
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intracranial masses:
Incorrect: Intracranial masses can be seen in patients with Turcot syndrome, which can be a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or Lynch syndrome. Patients with FAP-associated Turcot syndrome typically develop medulloblastomas, whereas those with Lynch syndrome-associated Turcot syndrome typically develop glioblastomas. This patient’s mucosal hyperpigmentation and presence of multiple hamartomatous masses on colonoscopy makes another underlying diagnosis more likely.  
❌ Benign mandibular bone tumors:
Incorrect: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with Gardner syndrome typically present with multiple bone and soft tissue tumor growths, as well as hundreds of adenomas on colonoscopy. However, Gardner syndrome would not give rise to the mucosal hyperpigmentation or hamartomatous polyps seen in this patient.
❌ Supernumerary impacted teeth:
Incorrect: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with Gardner syndrome typically present with hundreds of adenomas on colonoscopy, as well as multiple benign bone growths and supernumerary impacted teeth, none of which is seen in this patient. 
❌ Multinodular goiter:
Incorrect: Cowden syndrome is a genetic condition that can manifest with thyroid disorders as well as benign breast conditions. This syndrome also results in multiple gastrointestinal polyps and cutaneous manifestations. However, in Cowden syndrome, skin manifestations typically result in papules and hyperkeratosis, as opposed to hyperpigmentation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office with complaints of pain in the hip joint and stiffness in the lower back for the past month. The symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with activity and exercise. Review of systems reveals intermittent abdominal pain and frequent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea for the last 3 months. He tried over-the-counter analgesics, which helped the joint pain but made the diarrhea worse. He does not have any pain with urination and has not traveled recently. The remainder of his history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild tenderness in the hip joints and limited spinal flexion. Laboratory analysis is shown below:

 
 Laboratory value  Results 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9.8 g/dL 
 Platelet count  460,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  8,000/mm3 

Plain radiographs show signs of sacroiliac joint inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s joint pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with pain in the hip joint, morning stiffness that improves with activity, together with radiographic evidence of spondylitis, is highly suggestive of a seronegative spondyloarthropathy (SpA). His history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain makes inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)-related arthritis the most likely cause.

IBD is an immune-mediated condition that is divided into two types; ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn disease. It usually presents with abdominal pain and watery diarrhea (more commonly bloody in ulcerative colitis). Various extra-intestinal manifestations are associated with IBD, including pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, episcleritis, uveitis, oral ulcerations and spondyloarthropathy (SpA).

IBD-associated SpA usually manifests with sacroiliitis and spondylitis (low back or hip pain with stiffness that improves with movement), peripheral arthritis (most commonly involving the knee), enthesitis (inflammation and tenderness where tendons insert on joint) and dactylitis (sausage fingers). Most of the affected patients are HLA-B27 positive (characteristic of seronegative arthropathy). The diagnosis is usually made on colonoscopy and radiographic evidence of sacroiliitis. Treating IBD adequately also improves the symptoms of IBD-associated SpA.



Option Analysis

❌ Hip osteoarthritis:
Incorrect: Hip osteoarthritis is a common form of arthritis that can present with insidious pain in the hip joint. However, it is usually associated with certain risk factors (e.g., age >50, obesity) and presents on radiography with joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and cysts, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Reactive arthritis:
Incorrect: Reactive arthritis may follow 2-3 weeks after the onset of infectious diarrhea caused by Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter or Shigella. It is usually associated with a travel history, concomitant urethritis, uveitis, and cutaneous rash (e.g., keratoderma blennorrhagica, balanitis circinata), none of which are observed in this patient.
✅ Inflammatory bowel disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone (not joint) that involves the periosteum, medullary cavity or the cortical bone. It usually presents with erythema, redness, warmth and swelling of the affected bone, along with fever. Normal leukocyte count and gradual onset are atypical.
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that is characterized by peripheral erosive arthritis. Involvement of the axial skeleton is rare. Though extraarticular manifestations are common (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), gastrointestinal tract involvement is uncommon.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the office for recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. He has had several episodes of watery diarrhea in the past 2 years. Review of systems reveals a 9-kg (20-lbs) weight loss over this time period, fatigue, and loss of appetite. Past medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease and diabetes mellitus type II. He takes aspirin and glyburide regularly. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 19 kg/m2. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Colonoscopy shows erythematous and edematous bowel wall mucosa involving the whole colon. After appropriate workup, a colectomy is performed; findings of the involved regions are shown.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who has constitutional symptoms (fatigue, loss of appetite, weight loss), recurrent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain with gross morphological findings of pancolitis likely has ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Unlike Crohn disease (which can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract with relative rectal sparing), UC mostly involves the rectum and may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve other parts of the colon. Clinically, it presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.



Though nonspecific, colonoscopy findings in UC include loss of vascular markings due to engorgement of the mucosa, giving the colon an erythematous appearance. In addition, pseudopolyps, edema, erosions, friability, and spontaneous bleeding may be observed. Histological features include crypt abscesses, mucin depletion and basal lymphoidaggregates. UC is associated with increased risk of development of colorectal cancer, and thus colectomy is both therapeutic and preventative.  

Option Analysis

❌ Crohn disease:
Incorrect: Clinically, Crohn disease can present similarly; however, gross morphology usually reveals skip lesions (focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa) that result in a cobblestone appearance. Moreover, grossly bloody stools are uncommon until late in the disease course.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranous colitis is a manifestation of C. difficile infection, which clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. The infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins), and typical colonoscopy findings include pseudomembranes on the inflamed colonic mucosa. Bloody diarrhea and pancolitis are unlikely.
❌ Collagenous colitis:
Incorrect: Collagenous colitis is characterized by chronic, watery, non-bloody diarrhea with normal appearance of the colon on endoscopy. Macroscopic features can include slight edema, erythema, friability, exudative lesions, and scars, but these findings are uncommon. Diagnosis is made on biopsy findings of subepithelial collagen band >10 micrometers in diameter.
❌ Ischemic colitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic colitis can be secondary to embolic or thrombotic occlusion of mesenteric vessels; it typically presents with postprandial pain or the classic finding of abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. Instead, this patient with long-standing diarrhea, abdominal tenderness, and continuous inflammation of colon most likely has UC.
✅ Ulcerative colitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with Crohn ileocolitis presents to the office because of urinary burning, urgency and frequency since yesterday. She also reports passage of air at the end of urination. Review of systems reveals fatigue, weight loss, and intermittent diarrhea. Past medical history is significant for 3 urinary tract infections in the past 6 months treated with antibiotics, as well as Crohn disease, for which she is currently taking 5-aminosalicylic acid. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple aphthous ulcers on the oral mucosa and a mildly distended lower abdomen with tenderness. Urinalysis reveals brown-colored urine with positive nitrites. Serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with irritative symptoms (urgency and frequency) and pneumaturia, together with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTI), is consistent with colovesical fistula (CVF) secondary to Crohn disease.

A CVF is described as an atypical connection between the colon and urinary bladder. It most commonly develops as a complication of diverticulitis, malignancy, or Crohn disease (as in this patient). In the case of Crohn disease, long-standing transmural inflammation of the bowel wall can lead to erosion into the adjacent organ(s), resulting in fistula formation. If such erosion involves the bladder, it presents with irritative lower urinary tract symptoms (e.g., dysuria, frequency, urgency), pneumaturia (air in urine) and/or fecaluria (feces in urine). A history of recurrent UTI secondary to anaerobic organisms (e.g. E. coli) can also be seen. Diagnosis is confirmed on abdominopelvic computed tomography (CT) scan with oral or rectal contrast, and the imaging will illustrate air or contrast in the bladder with adjacent colonic wall thickening.



Other common complications of Crohn disease include malabsorption (due to associated ileitis), increased risk of colorectal cancer, abscess formation, strictures and perianal disease.



Option Analysis

❌ Bladder cancer:
