Incorrect: Bladder cancer usually presents with gross hematuria. Long-term smoking is the major risk factor. Storage (irritative) urinary symptoms can sometimes be present due to secondary urinary infection, but pneumaturia is unlikely.
✅ Colovesical fistula:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emphysematous pyelonephritis :
Incorrect: Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a necrotizing infection of renal parenchyma that usually presents with fever, chills, flank pain, nausea and vomiting. A normal serum creatinine would be atypical.
❌ Toxic megacolon:
Incorrect: Toxic megacolon, which is a nonobstructive colonic dilatation, is a potentially lethal complication. It is a surgical emergency that commonly presents with severe bloody diarrhea, abdominal distension, and hemodynamic instability (fever, tachycardia, and hypotension). Long-standing intermittent watery diarrhea with urinary frequency and pneumaturia are unlikely.
❌ Urethral diverticulum:
Incorrect: Urethral diverticulum refers to the out-pouching of urethral mucosa into the mid-to-distal urethra. It usually presents with post-void dribbling, dyspareunia or dysuria. Gastrointestinal symptoms with pneumaturia are atypical.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. The patient reports dull, cramping pain primarily over his left abdomen for the past three days. He additionally reports several episodes of non-bloody diarrhea, fevers, and chronic constipation. He was seen by his primary care physician for his symptoms and was given a course of antibiotics, but his symptoms have persisted. He reports an episode of diarrhea this morning. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His surgical history is notable for a cholecystectomy at age 44. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 162/94 mmHg. Physical examination shows a non-distended abdomen with tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant with rebound and guarding. Laboratory results show an elevated leukocyte count. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Rupture of vasa recta into the colonic lumen
Impaction of a fecalith in the distal ileum
Perforation of an outpouching of the ileal mucosa, submucosa, and serosa
Scar tissue resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction
Sudden interruption of blood flow to the small bowel

questions.solution:
Diverticulitis refers to an inflammation of outpouchings in the colon known as diverticula. Diverticulosis and diverticulitis are diseases primarily seen in Western nations, and they are thought to be due to diets low in fiber. The exact pathogenic mechanism for diverticula formation is unknown, but one theory suggests that diverticula form in response to increased intracolonic pressures generated when the colon is processing smaller, non–fiber-containing stools. This increased pressure eventually pushes out part of the colon, forming sac-like appendages at the weakest segments, at the point where the colon is fed by blood vessels called the vasa recta.  

When a diverticulum becomes obstructed with a small amount of stool, this leads to stasis, inflammation, and infection. Most cases of diverticulitis classically present with focal left lower quadrant abdominal pain and the generalized symptoms of malaise, low grade fevers, and alternating constipation and diarrhea. Uncomplicated diverticulitis involving microperforations can be diagnosed clinically and responds well to outpatient oral antibiotic therapy. Patients with concern for complicated diverticulitis involving macro-perforations, failure of outpatient therapy, or diagnostic uncertainty should undergo CT of the abdomen and pelvis with both IV and oral contrast, and they should then be admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics. Risk factors for the development of complicated diverticulitis include older age, failure of outpatient therapy, and immunocompromised patients. If left untreated, diverticulitis can progress to fistula formation and the development of intra-abdominal abscesses, leading to sepsis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Rupture of vasa recta into the colonic lumen:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of diverticular bleeding, which usually presents with painless hematochezia. The formation of diverticula occurs at the weakest point of the colonic wall, where it is fed by blood vessels called the vasa recta. When these vessels rupture, they can bleed into the colonic lumen.   
❌ Impaction of a fecalith in the distal ileum :
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of appendicitis. While this patient exhibits peritonitis and findings concerning for a surgical abdomen, his pain is primarily in the left lower quadrant, whereas appendicitis typically presents in the right lower quadrant.  
✅ Perforation of an outpouching of the ileal mucosa, submucosa, and serosa  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Scar tissue resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: This patient has a prior history of cholecystectomy, making adhesions and subsequent small bowel obstruction a possible cause of his abdominal pain. However, bowel obstruction is unlikely in this patient given his recent passage of stool and non-distended abdomen.   
❌ Sudden interruption of blood flow to the small bowel :
Incorrect: This describes acute mesenteric ischemia, which typically occurs in patients with risk factors for embolus formation (i.e. atrial fibrillation) or preexisting atherosclerosis. Patients typically present with periumbilical pain that is disproportionate to physical findings, as well as nausea and vomiting. This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a different condition.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman returns to her physician 1 week after a screening colonoscopy revealed invasive colorectal cancer. The physician discusses various treatment options, including surgical management and adjuvant chemotherapy. The patient inquires about her carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level, which she noticed on her laboratory report, and asks why the doctor ordered it. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient?

choices.text: “CEA levels will help us monitor the effectiveness of our treatment.”
“An elevated level of CEA is diagnostic for colorectal cancer.”
“CEA levels help us determine the staging of the tumor.”
“CEA levels help us determine the grading of the tumor.”
“CEA levels will help us determine what type of chemotherapy to use.”

questions.solution:
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a glycoprotein that is involved in cell adhesion; it is produced in the embryonic pancreas, intestine, and liver. Elevated CEA levels are often detected in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC). However, the CEA level is not specific for colon cancer, and it is often elevated in patients who smoke, as well as patients with other conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, cirrhosis, and pancreatitis. Therefore, because of its poor specificity, CEA levels cannot be used for screening or diagnostic purposes. Due to these limitations, CEA levels can be only used to monitor the effectiveness of current treatment, as well as to monitor for future recurrence of colorectal cancer. A rising CEA level after surgical resection and adjuvant chemotherapy suggests recurrent disease and should prompt follow-up imaging.  

A complete colonoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of CRC, due to its high sensitivity and specificity. Colonoscopy also allows for biopsy of suspicious masses, and subsequent histological analysis can determine whether they are indeed cancer and the depth of invasion.  

Option Analysis

✅ “CEA levels will help us monitor the effectiveness of our treatment.”:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ “An elevated level of CEA is diagnostic for colorectal cancer.”:
Incorrect: Although elevated levels of CEA are seen in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC), the finding is not diagnostic for CRC, due to significant overlap with benign disease. A colonoscopy with subsequent pathological examination is required for the diagnosis of CRC. 
❌ “CEA levels help us determine the staging of the tumor.”:
Incorrect: Although elevated levels of CEA are seen in patients with colorectal cancer, the test is not used for staging of the tumor. Staging requires assessing the size and extent of the main tumor, the number of nearby lymph nodes involved, and evaluation for metastasis. 
❌ “CEA levels help us determine the grading of the tumor.”:
Incorrect: CEA levels do not help in determining the tumor’s grade. Grading of a tumor describes the degree of tumor differentiation, which can only be determined histologically. 
❌ “CEA levels will help us determine what type of chemotherapy to use.”:
Incorrect: Although elevated levels of CEA are seen in patients with colorectal cancer, the test is not useful in determining the treatment plan. Most patients with CRC require surgical resection of the tumor, along with adjuvant chemotherapy, regardless of the CEA levels.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. She does not have any abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease. There is no family history of colorectal cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, which reveals a few polyps in the colon. The polyps are biopsied and examined for abnormal histology. Which of the following pathologic findings is at the highest risk for malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
The most common and clinically important neoplastic polyps are adenomatous polyps, as they give rise to the majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Adenomatous polyps are characterized by the presence of epithelial dysplasia. They are caused by a mutation in adenomatous polyposis coli (APC), a tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 5 that is responsible for regulating cell growth and adhesion. The two predictors of a polyp’s likelihood of undergoing malignant transformation are: 1) size and 2) histological appearance.  

Increasing polyp size is the most important characteristic that correlates with malignancy risk. Adenomatous polyps less than 1-cm are less likely to acquire subsequent mutations and undergo malignant transformation. In contrast, adenomatous polyps greater than 4-cm are much more likely to progress to adenocarcinoma.    

Furthermore, based on histological appearance, there are three types of adenomatous polyps: villous, tubular, and tubulovillous. Villous polyps, which have a cauliflower-like appearance, have the highest malignant potential. Tubular polyps, which are pedunculated polyps that protrude out into the intestinal lumen, have the lowest malignant potential. Tubulovillous polyps, which have characteristics of both tubular and villous polyps, have an intermediate malignant potential.    

Clinically, adenomatous polyps are mostly asymptomatic. In some cases, they can cause bleeding, secretory diarrhea, and partial intestinal obstruction.
 

Option Analysis

✅ 4-cm villous adenomatous polyp:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 3-cm villous adenomatous polyp:
Incorrect: Villous adenomas are more likely to undergo malignant transformation than other subtypes of adenomatous polyps. However, amongst villous polyps, those of greater size are at higher risk of malignant transformation. Therefore, another answer choice is at higher risk of malignant transformation.
❌ 2-cm tubulovillous adenomatous polyp:
Incorrect: Tubulovillous adenomatous polyps, which have characteristics of both tubular and villous polyps, have an intermediate malignant potential.
❌ 2-cm tubular adenomatous polyp:
Incorrect: Tubular adenomatous polyps are pedunculated polyps that protrude out in the lumen of the intestine. They have lower malignant potential than villous or tubulovillous polyps.
❌ 3-cm inflammatory polyp:
Incorrect: Inflammatory polyps are non-neoplastic projections of mucosa consisting of stromal and epithelial components as well as inflammatory cells. They are commonly seen in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease. Inflammatory polyps do not undergo neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to his physician by his mother due to headaches and difficulty walking for the past several weeks. The patient has had worsening nausea, vomiting, and irritability over this same time period. He has also been experiencing recurrent constipation and has occasionally noticed blood in his stool. The patient’s father and paternal grandmother died before the age of 50 from colon cancer. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a broad-based gait and head bobbing. Nystagmus is present. Rectal examination reveals guaiac-positive brown stool. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with signs concerning for an intracranial mass (e.g., headaches, nausea, ataxia). In addition, he has signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and a family history of colorectal cancer. In combination, these findings are concerning for Turcot syndrome.    

Turcot syndrome can be associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome; the differences can be seen in the number of polyps present on colonoscopy, as well as the type of intracranial mass that forms.    

Turcot syndrome as a variant of FAP is seen in two-thirds of Turcot cases. It is characterized by hundreds of intestinal adenomas and tumors of the central nervous system. The condition is caused by APC gene mutations, and patients are likely to develop medulloblastomas. Medulloblastomas are highly malignant tumors derived from primitive neuroectodermal tissue and most commonly arise in the cerebellum. Therefore, patients typically present with signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., broad-based gait, nystagmus). Additionally, patients may have features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema, headache, vomiting).    

Turcot syndrome as a variant of Lynch syndrome is seen in the remaining one-third of Turcot cases and is characterized by few intestinal adenomas as well as tumors of the central nervous system. The condition is caused by mutations in one of several genes involved in DNA mismatch repair (e.g., MSH2, MLH1). Lynch syndrome-associated Turcot syndrome typically gives rise to glioblastomas. These patients may also present with signs of elevated intracranial pressure, but they typically lack signs of cerebellar dysfunction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Turcot syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Gardner syndrome:
Incorrect: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with Gardner syndrome typically present with multiple bone and soft tissue tumor growths, congenital hypertrophy of the retinal epithelium, and supernumerary impacted teeth. However, none of these symptoms are seen in this patient.
❌ Peutz-Jeghers syndrome:
Incorrect: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is a genetic condition that causes the growth of multiple hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, which can similarly cause features of obstruction and hematochezia. However, patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome also present with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Cronkhite-Canada syndrome:
Incorrect: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is a nonfamilial condition that also results in polyposis in the gastrointestinal tract. Patients typically present with alopecia and cutaneous hyperpigmentation. This patient’s symptoms and family history make another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Cowden syndrome:
Incorrect: Cowden syndrome is a condition that results in multiple gastrointestinal polyps, as well as prominent skin manifestations (e.g., papules, hyperkeratosis). These patients are at increased risk of developing thyroid disorders and benign breast conditions (e.g., fibroadenomas). This patient’s symptoms suggest a different underlying condition.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. He reports that the pain is cramping in nature and is confined to the right lower quadrant. The diarrhea is watery in consistency and is not associated with food intake. He has had these symptoms for 2 years but has not previously sought medical attention. Past medical history is significant for joint pain. Family history is significant for colorectal carcinoma in his paternal grandfather. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Abdominal examination reveals mild right lower quadrant tenderness. Oropharyngeal examination reveals the following (shown below). Stool for occult blood is negative, and culture shows no bacterial growth. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on the colonoscopy of this patient?



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum
Cobblestone appearance of ileal and colonic mucosa
Small, flask-like out-pouchings in the cecum
Friable exophytic endoluminal mass in the ascending colon

questions.solution:
This patient with a chronic history of intermittent watery diarrhea, in combination with crampy abdominal pain and examination findings of anemia (pallor conjunctiva) and abdominal tenderness, is most likely suffering from Crohn disease (CD), an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).  

Crohn disease is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it can present with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Systemic findings of inflammation (low-grade fever, weight loss, anemia, fatigue, joint pains) can be seen. Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Macroscopic features typical of Crohn disease include:  

  •  Aphthous ulcers (Fig. A): small, discrete superficial ulcers, usually the earliest lesions seen in Crohn disease. This finding was apparent on this patient’s oropharyngeal exam. 
  •  Skip lesions (Fig B): Large ulcers with normal mucosa in between, typical of the segmental distribution of Crohn disease. 
  •  Cobblestone appearance (Fig C): Characterized by nodular thickening, with deep linear or serpiginous ulcers. Rectal sparing is a distinct feature. 
  •  Creeping fat (Fig D):  Characterized by fibrofatty proliferation of the mesenteric tissue adjacent to chronically inflamed bowel loops. 

   Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons


Figure B (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure C (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure D (Retrieved from: Radiopaedia.org)

Option Analysis

❌ Atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum:
Incorrect: Atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum is typical of celiac disease, which usually presents with foul-smelling bulky diarrhea and flatulence that is associated with dietary intake of gluten. This patient’s long-standing watery diarrhea is not associated with food intake.  
✅ Cobblestone appearance of ileal and colonic mucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small, flask-like out-pouchings in the cecum:
Incorrect: Diverticula are small, flask-like out-pouchings containing only mucosa and submucosa without a serosal layer. They are seen in diverticulosis and are usually asymptomatic, but they may present with bleeding. The condition is common in patients with long standing constipation and does not usually cause right lower quadrant pain.
❌ Friable exophytic endoluminal mass in the ascending colon:
Incorrect: A friable exophytic endoluminal mass in the ascending colon can be seen in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC), which usually presents with hematochezia and altered bowel habits. Although a family history of CRC increases the risk, a long-term history of intermittent watery diarrhea and negative fecal occult blood makes another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Flask-shaped ulcers in cecum:
Incorrect: Flask-shaped ulcers in cecum or colon are typically seen in intestinal Entamoeba histolytica infection. The condition is common in developing countries and usually presents with bloody diarrhea. A long-term history of watery diarrhea and negative fecal occult blood are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past 3 months. He reports that he defecates a small volume of stools 3-4 times a day, even after which he gets a sense of incomplete bowel emptying. The stools are semi-solid, admixed with a small amount of blood. Review of systems is significant for fatigue and loss of appetite. Vitals are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild distension and left-sided tenderness. Colonoscopy shows edematous and friable bowel wall mucosa extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon with small shallow ulcers throughout the involved region. This patient’s condition is most commonly associated with which of the following extraintestinal manifestations?

choices.text: Fibrosis and stricturing of the ducts in the biliary tree
Reduction in the aqueous component of tears
Pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces

questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, tenesmus and bloody diarrhea most likely has inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The colonoscopy findings of edematous and friable bowel wall mucosa extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon with small shallow ulceration throughout the involved region are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is an immune-mediated IBD that causes recurring episodes of inflammation of the rectum that may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve the sigmoid colon and beyond. Apart from the intestines, the immune-mediated destruction can sometimes involve certain extraintestinal organs. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is one such condition that is characterized by chronic, progressive fibrosis and stricturing of the ducts in the biliary tree. It can be asymptomatic or may present with jaundice, pruritus, and hepatosplenomegaly with a cholestatic pattern and increased alkaline phosphatase on liver function tests. Other extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, uveitis, and peripheral arthritis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Urinary calcium oxalate stones formation:
Incorrect: Calcium oxalate stones are a common complication of intestinal oxaluria observed in long-standing Crohn disease. It occurs when fatty-acids (which are not reabsorbed due to mucosal damage in the terminal ileum) make complexes with the Ca++ ions, leaving behind oxalate, thereby increasing oxalate reabsorption. The increased oxalate is excreted in the urine, which then combines with calcium, forming calcium oxalate stones.
✅ Fibrosis and stricturing of the ducts in the biliary tree:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Destruction of intralobular bile ducts:
Incorrect: Autoimmune destruction of intralobular bile ducts is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis, which is caused by a complex interplay of genetic and environmental factors (e.g., certain bacteria, viruses, or drug exposures). It is not associated with UC.
❌ Reduction in the aqueous component of tears:
Incorrect: Reduction in the aqueous component of tears (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) is observed in patients with Sjogren syndrome. Other clinical findings include dry mouth, oral candidiasis and vaginal dryness. It has no association with UC.
❌ Pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces:
Incorrect: Pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis. It is a dermal autoimmune reaction to dietary gluten that usually presents in association with celiac disease. It is not observed in patients with UC.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought by her son to the emergency room for evaluation of rapid-onset abdominal pain. The patient was watching television when her symptoms began suddenly. She describes the pain as constant and rates it as 9 out of 10 in severity. Past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation. She is currently taking atorvastatin and metoprolol. While in the emergency room, the patient has one episode of non-bilious, non-bloody vomiting. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, and pulse is 86/min and irregular. Physical exam shows diffuse abdominal tenderness. No bruising or signs of trauma are observed. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Atherosclerotic narrowing of intestinal blood vessels
Embolic occlusion of intestinal blood vessels
Telescoping of proximal bowel into distal bowel

questions.solution:
This patient has diffuse abdominal pain and a history notable for hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation. The most likely cause of her symptoms is acute mesenteric ischemia, which occurs when the blood supply to the small intestines is suddenly reduced, most often due to embolism or thrombosis of the superior mesenteric artery. The former is more likely in this patient, given her history of atrial fibrillation and irregular pulse on physical examination.  

Decreased blood flow causes bowel necrosis and results in severe abdominal pain. Later on, patients can develop hematochezia and red “currant jelly” stools, which occur when the necrotic mucosa sloughs off and mixes with blood and mucus to take on a jelly-like consistency.  

CT angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and it can identify the site of occlusion. Treatment options include vasodilator therapy, anticoagulant therapy, and surgical laparotomy with embolectomy.    



Option Analysis

❌ Atherosclerotic narrowing of intestinal blood vessels:
Incorrect: This describes the pathophysiology of chronic mesenteric ischemia. The condition causes abdominal pain that is worse 30-60 minutes after eating. This is because the atherosclerotic arterioles are unable to dilate in response to increased blood requirements. However, it would be atypical for chronic mesenteric ischemia to cause sudden onset abdominal pain in the absence of food consumption.  
❌ Inflammation of colonic outpouchings:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis occurs when colonic outpouchings, termed diverticula, become inflamed. Diverticulitis usually causes left lower quadrant pain. It can manifest with diffuse abdominal pain if the outpouchings rupture, leading to peritonitis. However, the patient’s history of hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation makes acute mesenteric ischemia a more likely explanation for the symptoms.   
✅ Embolic occlusion of intestinal blood vessels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Occlusion of the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: This describes bowel obstruction. The small intestines are more often affected due to their narrower caliber. The condition can cause severe abdominal pain and nausea, often leading to bilious emesis. However, patients with bowel obstruction usually have a history of abdominal surgery, which can cause adhesions, or may have a mass or malignancy impairing peristalsis.  
❌ Telescoping of proximal bowel into distal bowel:
Incorrect: Intussusception describes the telescoping of one portion of the intestines into the section distal to it. The condition most often affects children. It causes cyclical abdominal pain, “currant-jelly” stools, and a palpable mass in the abdomen. In contrast, this patient age, risk factors, and the timing of her pain are more concerning for acute mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. The symptoms began several months ago. She describes the diarrhea as bulky and foul-smelling. Over the past week, the patient also developed a pruritic rash on the bilateral forearms. Past medical history is significant for type I diabetes mellitus, which is well managed with insulin. She recently traveled to Mexico and ate food from local street vendors. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, as well as multiple tense, grouped blisters on her forearms and excoriations. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation. Laboratory testing reveals positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. If this patient’s condition is untreated, which of the following complications is she at greatest risk of developing?

choices.text: Dysplasia and subsequent neoplastic growth in the colon
Migratory arthralgias of the large joints

questions.solution:
This adolescent female is presenting with steatorrhea, dermatitis herpetiformis (pruritic rash on her forearms), and abdominal pain. Her laboratory testing is notable for anti-endomysial antibodies. As a result, she likely has celiac disease.

Celiac disease is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to gliadin in gluten-containing foods, which in turn activates T-cells. These activated T-cells release cytokines that ultimately damage the intestinal mucosa, resulting in flattened villi and crypt hyperplasia. Clinically, celiac disease can present with abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. It can also cause anemia, coagulopathy, and osteoporosis due to malabsorption of nutrients such as folate, vitamin K, and calcium. Cutaneously, it can cause dermatitis herpetiformis, which are small, pruritic vesicles that pop up symmetrically on the extensor surfaces. These lesions arise when circulating anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies bind and damage transglutaminase found in the dermal papillae of the epidermis.

In patients with refractory celiac disease, or in those who do not comply with gluten-free diets, there is chronic intestinal inflammation. This chronic inflammation of the small bowel can lead to uncontrolled proliferation of T-cells, resulting in enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL). Patients with celiac disease are also predisposed to other autoimmune endocrinopathies, such as hypo- or hyperthyroidism, type I diabetes mellitus, and selective IgA deficiency.

Option Analysis

✅ Neoplasm of the small bowel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by a preceding diarrheal illness, followed by the triad of thrombocytopenia, renal dysfunction, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Although this patient has diarrhea, she lacks other features consistent with HUS.
❌ Dysplasia and subsequent neoplastic growth in the colon:
Incorrect: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), especially ulcerative colitis (UC), is associated with increased risk of colon cancer. UC commonly causes recurring episodes of bloody diarrhea (although it can also be watery), and patients are often p-ANCA positive. This patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are inconsistent with those of UC. 
❌ Inflammation of the uvea:
Incorrect: Uveitis, which is inflammation of the uvea, can be an extraintestinal finding of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Patients with Crohn disease may test positive for anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies, whereas patients with ulcerative colitis may test positive for p-ANCA antibodies. This patient lacks clinical features and laboratory findings consistent with IBD.
❌ Migratory arthralgias of the large joints:
Incorrect: Migratory arthralgias can be seen in patients with reactive arthritis, which is characterized by a preceding diarrheal illness commonly caused by Shigella or Campylobacter. Reactive arthritis is usually associated with other clinical features, such as uveitis and urethritis, which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to his physician due to multiple, painless nodules on his jaw and forehead. He also has been experiencing recurrent constipation, and he has occasionally noticed blood in his stool. The patient’s mother died from colon cancer at the age of 42, and his maternal grandfather also died from colon cancer at a young age. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several bony growths on his mandible and forehead. Fundoscopic examination reveals multiple darkly pigmented lesions on the retina. Colonoscopy followed by genetic testing is performed, confirming the diagnosis. A mutation in which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with multiple osteomas on his face, as well as congenital hypertrophy of the retinal epithelium. He likely has Gardner syndrome, which is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).    

FAP is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by the presence of hundreds of adenomatous polyps lining the intestinal mucosal surface. These polyps have a near 100% chance for malignant transformation. The condition is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene located on chromosome 5; APC is a tumor suppressor protein, and mutations in this gene result in uncontrolled cell proliferation. Patients will have a family history of early-onset colon cancer and will often require a prophylactic colectomy to reduce the risk of developing colon cancer.  

Gardner syndrome, other than causing colon cancer, also causes prominent extracolonic bone and soft tissue tumors, such as osteomas, fibromas, lipomas, desmoid tumors, and epidermoid cysts. Moreover, a characteristic finding is bilateral, multiple, pigmented, ocular fundus lesions, known as congenital hypertrophy of the retinal epithelium. These patients can also have supernumerary impacted teeth, and multiple jaw osteomas and odontomas.  

Option Analysis

✅ APC:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ STK11:
Incorrect: Mutations in the STK11 gene are present in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Patients with this condition typically present with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, as well as multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. However, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome would not explain this patient’s bony growths or retinal lesions.
❌ MLH1:
Incorrect: Mutations in various DNA mismatch repair genes, such as MLH1, are seen in patients with Lynch syndrome. Patients are typically asymptomatic until the development of colorectal cancer; therefore, this patient’s other symptoms are suggestive of a different underlying diagnosis.  
❌ BRCA1:
Incorrect: Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are associated with the development of breast and ovarian cancer. Although there is also an association with colon cancer formation, this patient’s other symptoms suggest a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ MEN1:
Incorrect: Mutations in the MEN1 gene are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome, which results in pituitary tumors, parathyroid hyperplasia, and pancreatic adenomas.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain. She had lunch 5 hours ago, for which she had a beef steak. Review of systems reveals on-and-off watery diarrhea with abdominal pain for the past 2 years. She also experiences intermittent pain in her right knee which responds to ibuprofen. Past medical history is significant for an appendectomy with abscess debridement 6 months ago. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/86 mmHg. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness. Bowel sounds are normal on auscultation. Right upper quadrant ultrasound reveals thickening of the gallbladder wall with multiple stones inside. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Formation of adhesions after recent surgery
Loss of enterohepatic circulation of bile acids

questions.solution:
This patient with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever and tachycardia, together with ultrasonographic evidence of thickening of the gallbladder wall with stones inside the gallbladder, most likely has acute calculous cholecystitis. Her long-term history of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain is suggestive of ongoing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

IBD is an immune-mediated condition that is divided into two types; ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease (CD). CD is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it can present with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. The prevalence of gallstones is increased in patients with ileal CD. In this condition, gallstones are caused by the malabsorption of bile acids in the terminal ileum, which results in loss of their enterohepatic circulation. The end-result is depletion of bile salts, causing the buildup of lithogenic bile. Overtime, the stones can cause inflammation of the gallbladder or obstruction of the cystic duct, leading to acute calculous cholecystitis as seen in this patient. Other extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, uveitis, and peripheral arthritis.



Option Analysis

❌ Formation of adhesions after recent surgery:
Incorrect: Formation of adhesions are a normal response to the injury of peritoneal surfaces during surgery that can lead to intestinal obstruction. This extrinsic mechanical compression of the bowel usually presents with acute-onset nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and absent bowel sounds on auscultation. This patient has normal bowel sounds on auscultation.
❌ Ibuprofen use:
Incorrect: Common medications that increase the risk of gallstone formation include fibrates, prolonged use of ceftriaxone, octreotide, and estrogen analogs. Meanwhile, gastrointestinal side effects of ibuprofen include epigastric pain, heartburn, and peptic ulcer formation. Ibuprofen does not increase the risk of gallstone formation.
✅ Loss of enterohepatic circulation of bile acids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased reabsorption of oxalate:
Incorrect: Renal oxalate stone formation is a long-term complication of Crohn disease and occurs when fatty-acids (which are not reabsorbed due to mucosal damage) make complexes with calcium ions, leaving oxalate behind, thereby increasing its reabsorption. This reabsorption of oxalate increases the risk of formation of oxalate renal stones, which instead present with renal colic.
❌ Primary sclerosing cholangitis:
Incorrect: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by autoimmune destruction of biliary tree that is caused by inflammation, fibrosis, and stricturing of intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts. It is only seen in about 5% of the patients of Crohn disease and presents with jaundice, pruritus and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which are observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to his physician for a routine preventative examination. The patient’s past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and daily aspirin. His diet consists mainly of processed red meats with minimal vegetables and fruits. He consumes 1 glass of wine with his dinner daily. In the office, his blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and body mass index (BMI) is 34 kg/m2. The patient’s sister recently died from colorectal cancer, and he wants to know what is his own risk of developing this disease. Which of the following in this patient’s current lifestyle is protective against colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer worldwide. It most commonly affects individuals over 50-years-old, and in 25% of cases, there is a positive family history. The condition most commonly manifests in the rectosigmoid region, then ascending colon, and rarely the descending colon.  

Risk factors for colorectal cancer include hereditary factors (e.g. familial adenomatous polyposis) as well as the presence of adenomatous and serrated polyps on colonoscopy. Lifestyle factors, such as obesity, smoking, alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, and dietary factors, which include high consumption of processed red meat and decreased consumption of fiber, are associated with increased risk of CRC.    

Increased cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) activity is also linked to some forms of colon adenocarcinoma. The proposed theory is that COX-induced prostaglandin production leads to epithelial proliferation. Therefore, frequent use of COX enzyme inhibitors, such as NSAIDs and aspirin, can lower the risk of developing colorectal cancer. Furthermore, is associated with a decreased risk of CRC. This association is due to butyrate, a substance with antineoplastic properties which is synthesized by the gut microbiota as dietary fiber transits through the colon.  



Option Analysis

✅ Daily aspirin intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low-fiber diet:
Incorrect: Increased fiber consumption is associated with a decreased risk of developing colorectal cancer. This patient consumes minimal fruits and vegetables (high fiber-containing foods), which increases his risk of developing colorectal cancer. 
❌ Consumption of red meat:
Incorrect: Long-term consumption of red meat or processed meats is associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. The proposed reason is that high temperature cooking (e.g., barbecuing, pan-frying) produces polyaromatic hydrocarbons and other carcinogens. 
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity and type II diabetes mellitus are associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. Insulin is an important growth factor for colonic mucosal cells and stimulates colonic tumor cells. Patients with insulin resistance are likely to have increased serum insulin levels and hence an increased risk for colorectal cancer. 
❌ Statin use:
Incorrect: Statins are lipid-lowering drugs used to treat conditions such as coronary artery disease and hyperlipidemia. However, statins have not been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A heterosexual couple comes to the genetic counselor’s office for prenatal counseling. The woman has no significant past medical history, and her family history is not notable for any cancers. The man has a history of prophylactic colectomy at the age of 16 after a colonoscopy revealed hundreds of polyps. His father died at the age of 39 due to colorectal cancer, but his mother has been healthy. The couple is worried their children may also inherit this condition. What is the probability that this couple’s first child will inherit the disease?
questions.solution:
The male patient in this case had a prophylactic colectomy as a teenager and a first-degree relative who developed colon cancer at a young age. As a result, he most likely has familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder marked by the appearance of hundreds of colorectal adenomas by the teenage years. If untreated, most patients will die from colorectal cancer by the 4th decade of life.    

FAP is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene located on chromosome 5. APC is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a central role in Wnt signaling by regulating the degradation of β-catenin. Normally, in the presence of wild-type APC protein, β-catenin is degraded. However when APC is mutated, β-catenin and its target genes (e.g. c-myc) are overexpressed, resulting in uncontrolled cellular proliferation and eventual progression to cancer. Therefore, patients with FAP should receive annual screening colonoscopies and, if polyps are found, undergo prophylactic colectomy.  

Since FAP is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, only 1 mutant copy of the APC gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. This man’s father likely passed on a mutant copy of APC to him, whereas his mother was unaffected, and thus passed on a normal copy of APC. A heterozygous parent, such as this man, has a 50% chance of transmitting the condition. Therefore, his future child has a 50% chance of inheriting FAP.
 

Option Analysis

✅ 50%:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 25%:
Incorrect: Autosomal recessive diseases occur when an offspring inherits two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent). If both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance the child would inherit the condition. The man in this case likely has familial adenomatous polyposis, which is an autosomal dominant disease. 
❌ 0%:
Incorrect: This man likely has familial adenomatous polyposis, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Therefore, there is significant probability that this couple’s future child will also have a similar condition. 
❌ 75%:
Incorrect: This man likely has familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is caused by mutations in the APC gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. The woman has a noncontributory family history and does not have the mutated gene. As a result, this couple’s child has a 50% chance of inheriting the mutated APC gene from the man and developing FAP.
❌ 100%:
Incorrect: If the man in this case had been homozygous for the autosomal dominant trait, there would be a 100% chance the offspring would inherit the condition. However, homozygosity is exceedingly rare. In addition, the man’s mother did not display symptoms of the disease, meaning he likely only inherited one mutant copy of the APC gene from his father.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man comes to the office because of watery diarrhea and right lower quadrant pain. The symptoms started 3 months ago and are not relieved by over-the-counter antidiarrheals. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness to deep palpation in the right lower quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness. Rovsing sign is negative. Colonoscopy reveals focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa along with nodular mucosal changes in the colon. Biopsy findings of the involved tissue sample are shown.


 Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following cell types are the most involved in the formation of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations of chronic watery diarrhea and right lower quadrant pain, together with colonoscopy findings of skip lesions (focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa) and biopsy evidence of a noncaseating granuloma, are diagnostic of Crohn disease, an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) mainly mediated by Th1 cells.

Crohn disease is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. The damage is primarily mediated by Th1 cells, which secrete large amounts of interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) and interleukin-2 (IL-2), and macrophages, which release tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-ɑ) and other cytokines (e.g., IL-6, IL-12), likely in response to self-antigens. Macrophages help in Th1 cell differentiation, while Th1 cells promote further T-cell response, activation of macrophages, and differentiation of macrophages into giant cells. The end-result is formation of noncaseating granulomas containing epithelioid macrophages, which may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a band of lymphocytes, as seen in the biopsy image. Although these granulomas are actually only seen in a minority of patients with CD, when they are present, they are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.



Option Analysis

✅ T helper 1 (Th1) cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ T helper 2 (Th2) cells:
Incorrect: Th2 cells are mainly involved in the pathogenesis of ulcerative colitis (UC) by producing IL-5 and IL-13 which contribute to inflammation and damage of the intestinal mucosa. Enhanced Th2 (humoral) immunity in UC is evidenced by high levels of immunoglobulins and autoantibodies.
❌ Neutrophils:
Incorrect: Neutrophils are mainly involved in phagocytosis, and as such they instead play an active role in nonspecific inflammatory processes in response to injury or infection.
❌ B-lymphocytes:
Incorrect: B-lymphocytes transform into plasma cells which actively secrete antibodies that are involved in humoral immunity. However, noncaseating granulomas are mainly formed by cell-mediated immunity.
❌ Eosinophils:
Incorrect: Eosinophils mediates defense reactions against helminthic infections. They are also implicated in the pathogenesis of hypersensitivity reactions, eosinophilic vasculitis and a few types of Hodgkin lymphoma, but they are not actively involved in pathogenesis of IBD.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to changes in his bowel habits. The patient reports he has been experiencing alternating episodes of loose stools and constipation over the past several months, with associated cramping abdominal pain. The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. His past surgical history is notable for an appendectomy at age 18. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 137/94 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen without focal tenderness, rebound, or guarding. A fecal occult blood test is positive. The patient undergoes a colonoscopy that demonstrates outpouchings of the colonic mucosa and submucosa in the descending colon. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this disease process?

choices.text: Increased intraluminal pressure at points of vascular penetration
Failure of involution of the vitelline duct
Telescoping of a proximal colon segment into a distal segment
Erosion of adjacent loops of bowel due to full thickness granulomatous inflammation
Outpouchings surrounding a vestigial lymphoid structure

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with alternating constipation, diarrhea, and colickly abdominal pain with a colonoscopy that reveals outpouchings of the mucosa and submucosa. Together, these findings are consistent with a diagnosis of diverticulosis. Diverticulosis is the presence of multiple false diverticula, or pseudodiverticula, which occur only when the mucosa and submucosa outpouch. They are thought to be due to prolonged increased intraluminal pressure from diets poor in fiber at the weakest points of the gastrointestinal tract, where the vasa recta perforate the muscularis externa. Diverticula may also bleed intermittently, resulting in anemia or a positive fecal occult blood test, or they may become infected, resulting in diverticulitis.  

In contrast to false diverticula, true diverticula, such as a Meckel's diverticulum or inherited diverticula of the appendix, contain all layers of the bowel wall. True diverticula are much less common in comparison to false or pseudodiverticula.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased intraluminal pressure at points of vascular penetration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Failure of involution of the vitelline duct:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of a Meckel's diverticulum, which contains all layers of the colonic wall, not just the mucosa and submucosa. Meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct, and it is the most common congenital malformation of the gastrointestinal tract. It usually presents in pediatric patients with painless hematochezia, or it is discovered incidentally during colonoscopy at the terminal ileum.  
❌ Telescoping of a proximal colon segment into a distal segment  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of intussusception, which occurs when a lead point (such as a Meckel's diverticulum, lymphoid tissue, or tumor) causes the proximal end of bowel to peristalse into the more distal end. Intussusception can present with colicky abdominal pain in both pediatric patients and adults, although it is much more common in the pediatric population. Intussusception is unlikely in this patient without an identifiable lead point visualized on colonoscopy.   
❌ Erosion of adjacent loops of bowel due to full thickness granulomatous inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer describes fistula formation due to Crohn's disease, which results in full thickness inflammation of all layers of the colon or small bowel. While Crohn’s disease can present with hematochezia or a positive fecal occult blood test, it is generally associated with additional constitutional symptoms such as weight loss, arthralgias and fever.   
❌ Outpouchings surrounding a vestigial lymphoid structure  :
Incorrect: Diverticula can form around the appendix resulting in an increased risk of obstruction and subsequent appendicitis; however this patient’s appendix has been removed, and his diverticula are noted in the more distal colon, away from the site of the appendix.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue and weakness. The symptoms began 6 months ago and have progressively worsened. The patient has occasionally seen bright red blood in her stool since symptom onset. She denies constipation, straining, or trauma. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/68 mmHg. Physical exam shows conjunctival pallor. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh ejection-type systolic murmur at the second right intercostal space. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin of 8.9 mg/dL and serum iron level of 47µg/dL. Endoscopy is performed, and the results are notable for the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Neoplastic proliferation of colonic epithelial cells
Benign overgrowth of colonic mucosal tissue
Blood vessel dilation in response to VEGF overproduction
Inflammation characterized by continuous colonic and rectal involvement

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of subacute gastrointestinal bleeding, in combination with the endoscopy findings, is most consistent with intestinal angiodysplasia. The condition develops when small blood vessels in the mucosa and submucosa become dilated. Although the exact cause is unclear, it is suspected that increased levels of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and obstructed venous drainage contribute to the condition. Angiodysplasia most often occurs in the right colon. Angiodysplasia is often associated with advanced age (>60 years), von Willebrand disease, end-stage renal disease, and aortic stenosis (as evidenced by the patient’s harsh ejection-type systolic murmur at the second right intercostal space).  

Most individuals with intestinal angiodysplasia are asymptomatic. However, mild or severe bleeding can occur. Over time, bleeding from intestinal angiodysplasia can lead to iron deficiency anemia, as seen in this patient’s low hemoglobin and serum iron levels.  

The diagnosis is often made incidentally during endoscopy in asymptomatic patients or during an endoscopic exploration for lower GI bleeding due to an unknown cause. The treatment for symptomatic patients is endoscopic obliteration of the affected vessels; this intervention is not indicated in asymptomatic patients.  

Option Analysis

❌ Neoplastic proliferation of colonic epithelial cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes colon cancer. The condition can also cause GI bleeding, anemia, and a positive fecal occult blood test. However, endoscopy would reveal a mass in the colon, rather than dilated blood vessels.  
❌ Benign overgrowth of colonic mucosal tissue:
Incorrect: This answer describes a colonic polyp. Polyps can bleed and result in a positive fecal occult blood test, but this patient’s endoscopic findings are more consistent with that of angiodysplasia than those of a colonic polyp.  
✅ Blood vessel dilation in response to VEGF overproduction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inflammation characterized by continuous colonic and rectal involvement:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis is an autoimmune condition that results in inflammation and ulceration of the colon and rectum. The condition has two peaks of onset: ages 15-30 years, ages 50-70 years. The condition can result in blood loss, anemia, and a positive fecal occult blood test; however, characteristic ulcerations would be seen on the patient’s endoscopy.  
❌ Inflammation of colonic outpouchings:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis occurs when colonic outpouchings, termed diverticula, become inflamed. Diverticulitis usually causes left lower quadrant pain. In contrast, it would be atypical for the condition to cause painless long-term blood loss that leads to iron deficiency anemia. Moreover, visualization of the diverticula would be expected on colonoscopy.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of recurrent bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence for the past several months. The patient has not had any recent illnesses. He recently started training to become a competitive bodybuilder and has been on a diet consisting of mainly protein shakes and yogurts. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient takes only a multivitamin daily. He recently traveled to China to visit his relatives. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds with no tenderness to abdominal palpation. He is administered 50 g of lactose orally. Three hours later, there is an increase in breath hydrogen content. Stool sampling reveals a decreased pH. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Genetically regulated reduction of lactase enzyme activity
Loss of intestinal brush border enzyme due to gastroenteritis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with recurrent bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence after consuming a lactose-heavy diet (e.g., yogurts, protein shakes with milk). He likely has primary lactose intolerance.

Primary lactose intolerance is caused by a decreased expression of the lactase gene and is the most common cause of lactose intolerance. The condition is heavily influenced by many genetic factors, such as race and ethnicity, and it occurs most frequently in Asian and African populations. Less common causes of lactose intolerance include secondary lactose intolerance, which can arise in the setting of inflammatory or infectious damage to the intestines, or congenital lactase deficiency, which is when the lactase enzyme is absent at birth.

Patients with lactose intolerance who continue to eat lactose-containing foods typically develop postprandial bloating, flatulence, and diarrhea (especially prominent in children and adolescents).

The hydrogen breath test can be used in the work-up of lactose intolerance. Hydrogen is produced as a result of bacterial fermentation of the undigested lactose. The hydrogen gets reabsorbed into the blood and subsequently exhaled via the lungs.  



Option Analysis

✅ Genetically regulated reduction of lactase enzyme activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth:
Incorrect: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine can occur due to blind intestinal loops, such as after surgery, or due to motility disorders. The bacteria can deconjugate bile acids, resulting in steatorrhea and malabsorption. However, this patient’s symptoms occurred after he began consuming lactose-heavy foods, which makes an alternative diagnosis more likely.
❌ Congenital lactase deficiency:
Incorrect: Congenital lactase deficiency is a severe gastrointestinal disorder that presents early in infancy with profuse watery diarrhea in infants fed with breast-milk or lactose-containing formula supplements. This patient is presenting at a much older age, which makes congenital lactase deficiency highly unlikely.
❌ Developmental lactose malabsorption:
Incorrect: Developmental lactose malabsorption occurs in premature (<34 weeks gestation) infants, and generally improves as the intestinal mucosa matures. This patient is presenting at a much older age, which makes this etiology an unlikely cause of his lactose malabsorption.
❌ Loss of intestinal brush border enzyme due to gastroenteritis:
Incorrect: Secondary (acquired) lactose malabsorption can occur in individuals who have underlying small bowel pathology (e.g. celiac disease) or recent gastroenteritis, which causes damage to the intestinal mucosa. This damage results in loss of the lactase enzyme, which is normally present in the intestinal microvilli. However, this patient has had no preceding infection, making this etiology an unlikely cause of his lactose malabsorption.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of excessive fatigue and weight loss over the past 3 months. Menses occur every 28 days without heavy flow or severe pain. The patient’s mother died of endometrial cancer at the age of 48. Vital signs in the office include temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse of 98/min, respirations of 14/min, and blood pressure of 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. Rectal examination is notable for guaiac-positive brown stool. Hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, and mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. Colonoscopy shows a mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the resected mass reveals adenocarcinoma, and further genetic testing reveals a mutation in the MLH1 gene. This patient’s cancer is most likely due to a primary defect in which of the following cellular processes?

choices.text: DNA repair in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with gastrointestinal bleeding and is shown to have adenocarcinoma of the colon. Taking into account her mother’s history of endometrial cancer at a young age, as well as genetic testing revealing a mutation in the MLH1 gene, this patient likely has hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC, also termed Lynch syndrome, is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in one of four DNA mismatch repair genes: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, or PMS2. These mutations cause subsequent DNA mismatches to occur in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences (microsatellites), resulting in microsatellite instability. Microsatellite instability likely affects genes that control cell growth, and accumulation of mutations drives the process of carcinogenesis.    

Colon cancer in patients with Lynch syndrome is usually right-sided and occurs in adults under 50 years of age. Right-sided colon cancers grow as exophytic masses but do not typically cause colon obstruction because the right-sided colon has a larger diameter than the left. Instead, right-sided tumors tend to cause chronic bleeding, eventually causing iron-deficiency anemia. Lynch syndrome is also associated with extraintestinal malignancies, such as endometrial, ovarian, stomach, and skin cancers.
 

Option Analysis

✅ DNA repair in regions of repetitive nucleotide sequences:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleotide excision repair:
Incorrect: Defects in nucleotide excision repair (NER) are seen in xeroderma pigmentosum, wherein there is an inability to repair pyrimidine dimers formed by UV exposure. Patients typically present with photosensitivity and UV radiation-induced skin cancers.
❌ Homologous recombination DNA repair system:
Incorrect: BRCA1 and BRCA2 are genes involved in homologous DNA repair. Mutations in these genes can predispose patients to developing breast and ovarian cancers. Colon cancers and endometrial cancers, as seen in this patient and her mother, are much less commonly associated with BRCA mutations. 
❌ Degradation of β-catenin :
Incorrect: The APC gene encodes a cytoplasmic protein responsible for promoting the degradation of β-catenin. Mutation in the APC gene results in the development of hundreds of adenomatous polyps. This patient’s colonoscopy revealed just one colonic mass. Moreover, genetic testing revealed a mutation in the MLH1 gene, which suggests a different underlying condition.
❌ Nonhomologous recombination DNA repair system:
Incorrect: Ataxia telangiectasia is a disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene, which is involved in nonhomologous DNA repair. Patients typically present at a very young age (typically before the age of 5) with ataxia, telangiectasias in the eyes and skin, as well as recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office to establish routine care. He reports intermittent diarrhea and on-and-off crampy abdominal pain for the past 2 years. The diarrhea is nonbloody and is not associated with food intake. Past medical history is significant for pain in his knee joints that partially responds to ibuprofen. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva and mild right lower quadrant tenderness. Colonoscopy later reveals focal linear ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa, along with nodular mucosal changes in the descending colon and ileum. The rectal mucosa is spared. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a long-term history of intermittent watery diarrhea, in combination with crampy abdominal pain and physical examination findings of anemia (pallor conjunctiva) and abdominal tenderness, is most likely suffering from Crohn disease (CD), an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

Crohn disease is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it can present with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Systemic findings of inflammation (low-grade fever, weight loss, anemia, fatigue) can be seen. Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Intestinal features typical of Crohn disease include:

  •  Aphthous ulcers: small, discrete superficial ulcers, usually the earliest lesions seen in Crohn disease. 
  •  Skip lesions (Fig A): Large ulcers with normal mucosa in between, typical of segmental distribution of Crohn disease. 
  •  Cobblestone appearance (Fig B): Characterized by nodular thickening, with deep linear or serpiginous ulcers. Rectal sparing is a distinct feature. 
  •  Creeping fat (Fig C):  Characterized by fibrofatty proliferation of the mesenteric tissue adjacent to chronically inflamed bowel loops.

Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure B (Retrieved from: ">Wikimedia Commons


Figure C (Retrieved from: Radiopaedia.org

Option Analysis

❌ Ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis usually presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and is characterized on colonoscopy by continuous involvement of the rectum and sigmoid colon with scattered pseudopolyps and friable mucosa. Skip lesions and cobblestoning are typical of Crohn disease.
✅ Crohn disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranous colitis is a manifestation of C. difficile infection that clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. The infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins), and typical colonoscopy findings include pseudomembranes on the inflamed colonic mucosa. Skip lesions, linear ulceration and cobblestoning of mucosa are unlikely.
❌ Ischemic colitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic colitis can be secondary to embolic or thrombotic occlusion of mesenteric vessels; it typically presents acutely with bloody diarrhea, postprandial pain, or the classic finding of abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. This patient with long-standing watery diarrhea unrelated to food intake and endoscopic evidence of skip lesions and cobblestoning of mucosa most likely has Crohn disease.
❌ Diverticulitis:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis is defined as inflammation of diverticula, which are seen on colonoscopy as small, flask-like outpouchings containing only mucosa and submucosa. Diverticulitis is common in patients with long-standing constipation, and it usually presents with fever, acute-onset left-sided abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. Long-standing intermittent watery diarrhea and episodic abdominal pain are atypical.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of recurrent bloating and diarrhea over the past 2 months. She has bulky and foul-smelling diarrhea that is often difficult to flush. The patient had a Roux-en-Y reconstruction 5 years ago for morbid obesity that was refractory to diet and lifestyle modifications. Since then, she has lost 45-lbs, which has significantly improved her daily life. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies demonstrate a hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 101 µm3. Serum electrolytes are normal. Stool analysis shows no occult blood and stool culture is negative. The patient is asked to ingest 25 g of D-xylose following an overnight fast. Urine concentration of D-xylose after several hours is 3.0 g (normal ≥4.5 g). The physician prescribes her oral antibiotics, and the test is repeated after 2 weeks. Subsequent urine concentration is 9.2 g. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Microbial overgrowth in the small intestine
Reduced secretion of pancreatic lipase and colipase
Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the small bowel
Villous blunting due to gliadin hypersensitivity

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of malabsorption (e.g., bloating, foul-smelling diarrhea). Taking into consideration her previous history of a Roux-en-Y bypass surgery and abnormal D-xylose test that normalizes after antibiotic therapy, she likely has small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).

SIBO can arise due to blind loop syndrome, which occurs when a portion of the intestines is bypassed and food no longer passes through it. Blind intestinal loops are vulnerable to stasis and bacterial proliferation. In SIBO, intestinal bacteria deconjugate primary bile acids, resulting in impaired dietary fat absorption and subsequent steatorrhea.

The D-xylose test measures the absorptive capacity of the small intestine and is used to determine whether defects in the intestinal mucosa are responsible for malabsorption. In cases of SIBO, increased bacterial proliferation results in impaired D-xylose absorption. Since the elimination of D-xylose is mostly renal, inadequate intestinal absorption leads to low urine D-xylose levels. In patients with SIBO, D-xylose absorption will often increase following a course of antibiotics.  





Option Analysis

✅ Microbial overgrowth in the small intestine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced secretion of pancreatic lipase and colipase:
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis is the most common cause of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency in adults. It can manifest with steatorrhea, diarrhea, and recurrent bloating. However, the D-xylose test in patients with pancreatic insufficiency is normal because the small bowel mucosa is undamaged, and as a result, the monosaccharide can be absorbed and subsequently excreted via urine.
❌ Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the small bowel:
Incorrect: Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the small bowel can be seen in patients with Crohn disease. Although Crohn disease tends to present in young adults with signs of steatorrhea, the D-xylose test would be abnormal even after antibiotic treatment, since the damaged bowel wall would still not be able to absorb the monosaccharide.
❌ Inadequate synthesis of bile acids:
Incorrect: Bile acids are essential for proper lipid digestion in the small bowel. D-xylose is a monosaccharide and can be absorbed by the small intestine even without bile. As a result, conditions that result in inadequate bile synthesis or release into the gastrointestinal lumen (e.g., cirrhosis, choledocolithiasis) would not affect D-xylose absorption.
❌ Villous blunting due to gliadin hypersensitivity:
Incorrect: Celiac disease is characterized by villous blunting secondary to gliadin hypersensitivity. Since celiac disease impairs proper small bowel absorption, it would result in an abnormal D-xylose test. However, antibiotics would be ineffective in treating celiac disease or improving intestinal D-xylose absorption.

questions.text:
A pathologist is examining the effects of different genetic mutations and changes in molecular signalling on colonic polyps. One specific colonic polyp she is examining is a sessile serrated polyp obtained from a 65-year-old patient. Biopsy of the polyp is shown below:

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Immunostaining for MLH1 and MSH2 proteins are negative. Which of the following best describes the underlying abnormality that enabled this polyp to grow?

choices.text: Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions
Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor

questions.solution:
This sample shows a serrated polyp. It likely arose due to CpG island hypermethylation and subsequent impaired synthesis of DNA repair proteins MLH1 and MSH2.  

Serrated polyps are one of two neoplastic polyps, with the other being adenomatous polyps. Serrated polyps are often flat or sessile and characterized by a “sawtooth” appearance on histology. A characteristic finding of these polyps is instability (hypermutability) in microsatellite regions, which are tandem repeats of nucleotides found throughout the genome. This finding arises due to hypermethylation of CpG islands located in DNA repair-genes. Since methylation leads to gene silencing, these changes result in reduced production of DNA repair proteins and an increased risk of developing mutations in microsatellite regions. Overtime, these mutations accumulate, enabling the polyp to grow and eventually progress to cancer.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased B-catenin synthesis:
Incorrect: The APC gene encodes a cytoplasmic protein that functions to promote the degradation of B-catenin. Mutations in the APC gene typically result in the development of adenomatous polyps, not serrated polyps. 
❌ Loss of serine-threonine kinase activity:
Incorrect: Mutations in the serine/threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene are present in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. These genes encode a tumor suppressor protein involved in cell signaling and apoptosis. As a result, mutations in this gene result in uncontrolled cellular growth. However, another answer choice is more commonly implicated in the pathogenesis of serrated adenomatous polyps.
❌ Impaired production of p53 protein:
Incorrect: A mutation in the TP53 gene results in reduced production of the tumor suppressor protein p53. Mutations in TP53 is a major contributor to the growth of adenomatous polyps. In contrast, serrated polyps have a different underlying genetic defect. 
❌ Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor:
Incorrect: A mutation in the RB gene results in impaired production of the protein retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma inhibits the transcription factor E2F. However, abnormalities in the RB gene or E2F protein regulation are not involved in the pathogenesis of serrated polyps.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to her physician for a routine preventative examination. The patient gets regular exercise and does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She states she has been feeling fine for the past year. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable. The patient expresses concern about undergoing colonoscopies because of the procedure’s invasiveness, and she wants to know when it is necessary to have one done. Which of the following risk factors, if present in this patient’s history, would warrant early screening for colorectal cancer?

choices.text: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis diagnosed at age 33.
The patient’s father developed colorectal cancer at age 70.
The patient has a history of irritable bowel syndrome.
The patient’s aunt was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 50.
The patient consumes a low-fiber diet.

questions.solution:
Screening for colorectal cancer (CRC) is essential in identifying premalignant lesions and detecting asymptomatic early-stage malignancy. Screening for colorectal cancer in low-risk individuals begins at the age of 50. Screening includes visualization methods, such as colonoscopy (the gold standard) and flexible sigmoidoscopy. In addition to direct visualization, laboratory testing can be used (such as fecal occult blood test), although these modalities are not as specific as direct visualization techniques.    

Some patients are at an increased risk of developing CRC and warrant screening at an earlier age. The age of beginning CRC screening varies, depending on the patient’s risk factors and family history. Patients who have a first-degree relative diagnosed with colon cancer before the age of 60 should begin screening at the age of 40 or 10 years prior to their relative’s diagnosis, whichever is earlier. In all patients with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., ulcerative colitis, Crohn disease) a screening colonoscopy should be performed eight years after disease or symptom onset. Additionally, patients with hereditary syndromes, such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC), require screening starting at an early age.
   

Option Analysis

✅ The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis diagnosed at age 33.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The patient’s father developed colorectal cancer at age 70.:
Incorrect: Patients with a family history of colorectal cancer (CRC) in a first-degree relative are at increased risk of developing the condition. This is the case regardless of the age at which the relative was diagnosed. However, early colonoscopy screening is warranted only if the first-degree relative was diagnosed at less than 60 years of age. 
❌ The patient has a history of irritable bowel syndrome.:
Incorrect: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is not associated with an increased risk of developing colorectal cancer. In contrast, inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, are associated with a higher risk of CRC, and therefore, these patients require earlier screening. 
❌ The patient’s aunt was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 50.:
Incorrect: Patients who have a first-degree relative with colorectal cancer diagnosed before the age of 60 should undergo earlier colonoscopy screening. The first colonoscopy should be performed at age 40 or 10 years prior to their relative’s diagnosis, whichever is earlier.
