However, the patient’s aunt is not a first-degree relative, and as a result, early colonoscopy testing is not necessary.
❌ The patient consumes a low-fiber diet.:
Incorrect: Although a low-fiber diet is associated with increased risk of developing colorectal cancer, earlier screening is not warranted based on diet alone.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother due to excessive fatigue over the past 2 months. The mother has occasionally noticed blood in the toilet bowl after the patient defecates. There is no significant family history of cancers. The patient's temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. No abnormal skin pigmentation is noted. Laboratory results are as follows:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.7 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  35% 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  74 μm3 
 
Colonoscopy is performed and reveals seven polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract; subsequent biopsy reveals hamartomatous mucosal polyps. Genetic testing is performed and reveals a mutation in the BMPR1A gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS) is caused by mutations in the BMPR1A and SMAD4 genes. The condition can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with incomplete penetrance or arise due to de novo mutations. These genes are involved in regulating the growth factor-beta (TGF-β) signaling pathway, and therefore, mutations can result in uncontrolled cellular proliferation.    

In JPS, affected individuals are typically symptomatic by age 20, with polyps often appearing in the first decade of life. This syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomas, which are composed of abnormal collections of tissue elements normally found within the intestinal tract. Most of these hamartomas are found in the colon and rectum. Patients commonly present with hematochezia and iron-deficiency anemia. Importantly, they are not only at risk for developing colorectal cancer but also for cancers in other areas of the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach, small intestine, pancreas).   

Diagnosis is made by endoscopic studies (e.g. colonoscopy) followed by biopsy. A patient meeting one of the below criteria can be diagnosed with JPS:  
1) More than five juvenile polyps in the colon or rectum  
2) Multiple juvenile polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract  
3) Any number of juvenile polyps in a person with a family history of juvenile polyposis syndrome 

Option Analysis

✅ Juvenile polyposis syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Peutz-Jegher syndrome:
Incorrect: Peutz-Jegher syndrome can also present with gastrointestinal bleeding and hamartomatous polyps in young children. However, this patient lacks the mucosal hyperpigmentation typically seen in Peutz-Jegher syndrome. Furthermore, the condition is usually caused by a mutation in the STK11 gene, as opposed to the BMPR1A gene.
❌ Familial adenomatous polyposis:
Incorrect: Familial adenomatous polyposis is caused by a mutation in the APC gene and results in hundreds of adenomatous polyps on colonoscopy. This patient’s hamartomatous polyps and genetic testing results suggest a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ Lynch syndrome:
Incorrect: Lynch syndrome is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2). Patients with Lynch syndrome are at increased risk of colorectal cancer. However, it would be unusual for the condition to cause multiple hamartomatous polyps or arise secondary to a BMPR1A gene mutation.
❌ Cronkhite-Canada syndrome:
Incorrect: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is a nonfamilial condition that also results in polyposis in the gastrointestinal tract. Patients typically present with alopecia and cutaneous hyperpigmentation. This patient’s symptoms and genetic testing results make another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain for the past 3 months. He states that he defecates a small volume of stools 3-4 times a day, even after which he gets a sensation of incomplete bowel emptying. The stools are semi-solid, admixed with a small amount of blood. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the abdomen shows mild distension and left-sided tenderness. Colonoscopy reveals edematous rectum, sigmoid and descending colon with loss of vascular markings and multiple pseudopolyps throughout the involved region. The mucosa is erythematous and friable, with spontaneous bleeding on contact. The remainder of the colon and small intestines are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent episodes of small-volume, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and tenesmus (sense of incomplete bowel evacuation). Colonoscopy findings of continuous bowel inflammation with pseudopolyps and friable mucosa are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).  

UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Clinically, it presents with recurrent small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may also have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Macroscopic features typical of UC include:    

  •  Continuous involvement of the colon (Figure A): Unlike Crohn disease (which can involve any part of the gastrointestinal tract with relative rectal sparing), UC commonly involves the rectum and may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve other parts of the colon 
  •  Loss of vascular markings (Fig. B): Due to engorgement of the mucosa, the bowel has an erythematous appearance. 
  •  Formation of pseudopolyps (Figure C): When the ulceration destroys significant portions of the mucosa, the residual mucosa protrudes above the surface of the ulcers in the form of polyps. Since these are not true neoplastic polyps, they are called pseudopolyps. 
  •  Friable mucosa (Fig D): Characterized by nodular thickening, with deep linear or serpiginous ulcers.  

Figure A


Figure B (Retrieved from: flickr.com)


Figure C (Retrieved from: flickr.com)


Figure D (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)  

Option Analysis

❌ Crohn disease:
Incorrect: Clinically, Crohn disease can present similarly; however, gross morphology usually reveals skip lesions (focal ulcerations adjacent to areas of normal appearing mucosa) that result in a cobblestone appearance. Moreover, grossly bloody stools are uncommon until late in the disease course.  
✅ Ulcerative colitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranous colitis is a manifestation of C. difficile infection that clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. The infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g., clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins), and typical colonoscopy findings include pseudomembranes on the inflamed colonic mucosa. Bloody diarrhea and pancolitis are unlikely.
❌ Ischemic colitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic colitis can be secondary to embolic or thrombotic occlusion of mesenteric vessels; the condition typically presents with postprandial pain or the classic finding of abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. This patient with long-standing diarrhea, abdominal tenderness and contiguous inflammation of the colon likely has a different diagnosis.
❌ Diverticulitis:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis is defined as inflammation of diverticula, which are small, flask-like outpouchings containing only mucosa and submucosa. The presence of such diverticula is common in patients with long-standing constipation. Although diverticulitis can cause left-sided abdominal pain, tenderness and tenesmus, the onset is acute and is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting and low-grade fever.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient states the pain is located near the upper mid-abdomen and that he has never experienced similar pain before. An upper endoscopy is performed which reveals a single, shallow, 1 cm ulcer in the first part of the duodenum. Biopsies do not reveal Helicobacter pylori, and stool testing for H pylori is negative as well. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient was evaluated in the emergency department two weeks ago for a transient ischemic attack, and he was started on a COX-1 and COX-2 inhibitor. This patient’s current presentation is a result of an adverse effect of which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s duodenal ulcer in the setting of a negative Helicobacter pylori test is most likely an adverse effect of aspirin therapy. Aspirin works by irreversibly inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 (via acetylation). At low doses, it predominantly inhibits COX-1; thereby, preventing platelet synthesis of thromboxane A2 and platelet aggregation. Inhibition of COX-1 in the stomach leads to a decrease in the concentration of cytoprotective prostaglandins, increased production of gastric acid, and decreased mucosal bicarbonate production. Together, these effects increase the risk of developing gastritis, gastric/duodenal ulcers or bleeding.  

Chronic aspirin use is associated with acute renal failure, interstitial nephritis and increased bleeding time. Additional side effects include hypersensitivity reactions such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and anaphylactic reactions. People with nasal polyps and asthma are also more prone to experience aspirin hypersensitivity–referred to as aspirin exacerbated respiratory disease.  Aspirin should not be provided to reduce fever in children with underlying viral infections, as it may lead to Reye’s syndrome–a condition characterized by liver damage and progressive encephalopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect:  Warfarin is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor that is used for chronic anticoagulation in patients with underlying atrial fibrillation or transient ischemic attack/stroke. Although it increases the risk of bleeding, it is not associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.
❌ Heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin can be used temporarily for anticoagulation in patients with transient ischemic attack/stroke. This medication is not associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.  
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor which helps decrease inflammation. It does not inhibit COX-1, thereby minimizing gastroduodenal toxicity.  
❌ Colchicine:
Incorrect: Colchicine inhibits microtubule formation by binding to tubulin. It is not indicated in the management of transient ischemic attack/stroke, nor is it associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain. His symptoms started four months ago. He has not seen any blood in his stool. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. He follows a balanced diet but has stopped consuming milk as it exacerbates the symptoms. He has not experienced any changes in weight or appetite. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following disease processes most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Presence of unabsorbed solutes in the intestines
Secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen
Inflammation of the intestinal wall with granuloma formation
Bacterial invasion of the intestinal wall with inflammatory cell infiltration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with crampy abdominal pain and intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is exacerbated by consuming lactose containing foods. These findings are suggestive of lactose intolerance, which is a type of osmotic diarrhea. Affected patients lack the enzyme lactase. As a result, lactose cannot be broken down and remains in the intestinal lumen, where it is osmotically active and prevents water absorption by the intestines.

Osmotic diarrhea occurs due to the presence of unabsorbed solutes (e.g. lactose) in the intestinal lumen. These unabsorbed solutes exert an osmotic power, trapping water in the lumen as well as drawing water into the lumen. Osmotic diarrhea is watery, non-bloody, and typically resolves when the causative substance (e.g., food, medication) is discontinued.

Another type of diarrhea is secretory diarrhea, which can occur in certain infections (e.g. Vibrio cholera) and some gastrointestinal disorders (e.g. VIPoma). It results from excessive secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen, which exerts an osmotic effect and sucks fluid from the surrounding tissues into the intestinal lumen. Secretory diarrhea is also watery, and non-bloody, but unlike osmotic diarrhea, persists even with decreased oral intake.

Moreover, there is inflammatory (exudative) diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is typically seen in patients with certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease) or bacterial (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni) invasion of the intestinal wall. These conditions lead to an inflammatory process that damages the intestinal epithelium. The diarrhea is usually purulent, bloody, and persists during fasting. Systemic symptoms such as fever, tachycardia, and weight loss may also be seen.

Finally, diarrhea can occur due to increased gastrointestinal motility, which causes water and nutrients to reach the colon too fast without adequate time for proper digestion and absorption. Potential etiologies include irritable bowel syndrome and hyperthyroidism.  

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of unabsorbed solutes in the intestines:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen:
Incorrect: Secretory diarrhea is due to the secretion of ions into the intestinal lumen. Examples of secretory diarrhea include infections (e.g. Vibrio cholera) as well as other conditions such as VIPoma. In contrast, this patient has intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is associated with milk ingestion, which is more suggestive of lactose intolerance.  
❌ Inflammation of the intestinal wall with granuloma formation:
Incorrect: Crohn disease is characterized by intestinal wall inflammation and granuloma formation. It is associated with inflammatory diarrhea that is often purulent and bloody. In contrast, this patient has intermittent non-bloody diarrhea that is associated with milk ingestion, which is more suggestive of lactose intolerance.  
❌ Bacterial invasion of the intestinal wall with inflammatory cell infiltration:
Incorrect: Certain bacteria (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, Shigella species) invade and destroy the epithelial lining of the intestinal wall and induce an inflammatory response. Bacterial infection typically presents acutely with bloody diarrhea and systemic manifestations (e.g. fever, chills). In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are suggestive of another underlying etiology.  
❌ Deficiency in pancreatic digestive enzymes:
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis and resulting pancreatic enzyme insufficiency leads to fat malabsorption and steatorrhea. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with lactose intolerance, which is due to a deficiency of the brush border enzyme lactase.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic due to 4 weeks of fatigue and malaise. The patient was diagnosed with Crohn disease 1 year ago and was initially treated with long-term glucocorticoids. Two months ago, the patient was weaned off glucocorticoids and switched to azathioprine. Temperature is 37.1 ºC (98.8 ºF), pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 122/78 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears pale, with scattered bruises over the body. Complete blood count is shown below. Decreased activity of which of the following enzymes could explain this patient's condition?

 Complete blood count (CBC)
 Hemoglobin  8.3 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  25% 
 MCV  85 fl 
 Reticulocyte count  1% 
 Leukocyte count  500/mm3 
 Platelet count  30,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe pancytopenia two months after starting azathioprine for Crohn disease. Severe or recurrent pancytopenia in patients taking azathioprine should raise the suspicion of decreased activity of thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT), an enzyme that is responsible for the degradation of the active metabolites of azathioprine.  

Azathioprine is a prodrug that gets converted to its active metabolite 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) by the action of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). 6-MP then inhibits purine synthesis, suppressing DNA and RNA synthesis and halting cellular division. These effects are most noted in actively dividing cells, including immune cells. In this way, azathioprine inhibits the proliferation of immune cells and suppresses the immune system. Azathioprine is used in autoimmune disorders (e.g., autoimmune hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease), and can also be used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients. The major side effects of azathioprine are bone marrow suppression and pancreatitis.  

Due to genetic polymorphism, some people have lower or absent activity of TPMT. Such people are more likely to develop bone marrow suppression due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites of 6-MP and azathioprine. Additionally, patients taking xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. allopurinol) concurrently with azathioprine or 6-MP are at increased risk of toxicity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thiopurine methyltransferase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: HGPRT is the enzyme responsible for converting azathioprine to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits purine synthesis. Decreased activity of HGPRT would result in decreased activity of the azathioprine and thus decreased side effects.
❌ Cytochrome p450:
Incorrect: Cytochrome p450 (CYP-450) is a group of hepatic enzymes that are responsible for the metabolism of numerous drugs and toxins. Polymorphism is seen in the cytochrome P450 system, which accounts for different activity levels in the population. Azathioprine is not metabolized by cytochrome p450
❌ Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of 5-fluorouracil. Decreased activity of this enzyme results in increased toxicity in patients taking 5-FU. However, it is not involved in azathioprine metabolism.
❌ Aldehyde dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Aldehyde dehydrogenase is responsible for breaking down acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate product of ethanol metabolism. Deficiency in this enzyme results in the accumulation of acetaldehyde after alcohol consumption, causing symptoms like facial flushing, headache, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the family medicine clinic accompanied by his parent due to a 4-week history of infrequent bowel movements. According to the parent, the child has had 2 bowel movements per week during which he strains. Previously, the child had one bowel movement per day. The patient has not had any abdominal pain or change in stool caliber or consistency. The patient feels pain while defecating and notices red streaks while wiping. The child takes no medications, is obese with a BMI of 32, and is otherwise healthy. The child started primary school 3 weeks ago. When asked about exercise, the parent states that he plays video games most of the day and goes for a short walk in the evening with the other parent. The child’s diet consists of fruits, vegetables, and meats. When asked if he drinks water during the day, the child shakes his head and says no. Which of the following is likely to contribute most to the child’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has a chief complaint of infrequent bowel movements. While there are defined criteria for defining constipation, such as the Rome III criteria and the Bristol stool scale, they are more often used in medical research than in clinical diagnosis. Typically, clinical constipation is defined as having fewer than 3 bowel movements per week.

This patient experiences pain while defecating and notices blood while wiping. These symptoms are characteristic of anal fissures. With prolonged constipation and subsequent hardening of stool, anal fissures can develop with forceful straining and anal distention. These fissures cause pain while defecating and deter efforts to have a bowel movement. Voluntary withholding then worsens constipation, and a cyclical pattern develops. Voluntary withholding (due to pain or other biopsychosocial causes) is a major cause of constipation in children.  

Option Analysis

❌ Recently starting primary school:
Incorrect: Functional constipation (constipation arising from an unknown etiology) is common in children and has been associated with several biopsychosocial risk factors. While recently starting primary school introduces new psychological stressors on the child, this explanation is unlikely since he started having symptoms one week before starting school.  
✅ Pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: While there are several risk factors associated with both obesity and constipation, such as long-term sedentary lifestyles and low-fiber diets, no direct association between obesity and constipation exists. Rather than developing constipation, overweight and obese adolescents may be more likely to have fecal incontinence.  
❌ Lack of exercise:
Incorrect: There is a long-held belief that bowel frequency increases in proportion to increased exercise; however, these findings are not evidence-based. Physical exercise has been shown to dramatically increase physical fitness; however, no consistent effect on large bowel function has been found. Therefore, while this patient should partake in more daily exercise, it should not have an impact on his recent symptoms of constipation.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Constipation is reported in nearly 60% of adults with diabetes mellitus. The cause of constipation remains poorly understood and likely involves long-term autonomic and enteric neuropathy. Patients with diabetes frequently suffer from enteropathic diarrhea and bloating due to the same pathophysiology. The child in this vignette has neither been diagnosed with diabetes nor does he present with any classical symptoms of diabetes such as polyuria, polydipsia, polyphasia or fatigue. Children with new-onset diabetes frequently present with nocturnal enuresis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for nausea, abdominal pain, and non-bloody vomiting for the past 24 hours. These symptoms are associated with decreased appetite. The patient is not sexually active. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation without guarding or rebound tenderness. CT of the abdomen shows dilated loops of the small bowel. A nasogastric tube is placed. Further history shows this patient has been taking excessive amounts of laxatives in an effort to lose weight. Which class of laxatives did this patient most likely misuse?
questions.solution:
Bulk-forming laxatives such as methylcellulose, polycarbophil, and psyllium are hydrophilic colloids derived from indigestible fruit and vegetable matter. They are commonly used over the counter to aid in constipation prevention or relief. These laxatives swell in the digestive tract as they absorb water. The distention of the intestinal walls caused by their swelling creates reflexive peristalsis. Bulk-forming laxatives require a significant amount of water in order to function. If taken without sufficient quantities of water, the bulk-forming laxative can become impacted, creating small bowel obstruction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Osmotic laxatives:
Incorrect:  Osmotic laxatives (magnesium salts, sodium sulfate, sorbitol), lactulose, and polyethylene glycol each function to draw water into the bowel lumen to promote large bowel motility. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
❌ Stimulant laxatives:
Incorrect: Stimulant laxatives such as senna and bisacodyl promote large bowel motility by direct inflammation of the bowel mucosa. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
✅ Bulk forming agents:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chloride channel activators:
Incorrect: Chloride channel activators such as lubiprostone cause a hyperosmotic effect, drawing water into the bowel lumen and thus promoting bowel motility. Small bowel obstruction is not a common adverse effect of this class of laxatives.  
❌ Opioid antagonists:
Incorrect:  Opioid antagonists such as alvimopan and methylnaltrexone are used for opioid-induced constipation (OIC). They block gastrointestinal mu-opioid receptors, which allows propagation of downstream acetylcholine signaling in cases of OIC.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the hospital for routine colonoscopy screening. The patient’s first screening colonoscopy 10 years ago was normal without any polyps. The patient has chronic constipation and routinely takes senna to help promote bowel movements. Prior to the colonoscopy, vital signs are unremarkable.  Physical exam does not show any abdominal distention or tenderness to palpation. During colonoscopy, dark pigmented spots are visualized in multiple locations throughout the colon. Which of the following most likely caused these findings on this patient’s colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
The dark spots throughout this patient’s colon are referred to as “melanosis coli.” Melanosis coli is caused by stimulant laxatives such as senna and bisacodyl. As the metabolic breakdown products of these laxatives pass through the colon, they become active and cause cell death and apoptosis in the lining of the colon, causing lipofuscin deposition (not melanin as the name might imply) and eventually dark pigmentation of the colon. Melanosis coli is not associated with an increased risk of colon cancer and resolves with the discontinuation of laxatives.

Stimulant laxatives act by causing direct inflammation of the colon, which in turn causes the colon to reflexively undergo peristalsis. Stimulant laxatives are meant to be used as short-term therapies for constipation, and should not usually be used on a chronic basis. Dietary alterations, patient education, and regular exercise are key first steps for the treatment of constipation, followed by bulking agents such as psyllium, if indicated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metastatic adenocarcinoma to the colon:
Incorrect: Metastatic adenocarcinoma to the colon would likely present with multiple masses visible on imaging and/or on colonoscopy. The findings on this patient’s colonoscopy of dark pigmented spots are not suggestive of any underlying masses. Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer may describe weight loss, fatigue, pencil-thin stools, hematochezia, or others.  
❌ Previous polypectomy:
Incorrect:  When found on colonoscopy, polyps are typically resected and harvested using an endoscopic snare for pathologic analysis in order to assess risk for possible malignancy. Minor bleeding may occur during cold or hot snaring. The finding in this patient’s colonoscopy of dark pigmented mucosa would not likely be from previous polyp resection sites from 10 years ago. More importantly, the patient’s previous colonoscopy is reported as normal.  
❌ Mucosal artifact from repeated colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A well-executed colonoscopy has virtually no chance of chronically irritating the bowel mucosa. Submucosal dissection and perforation are the most common adverse events associated with colonoscopy and carry approximately a 7% and 1% risk, respectively. These would not cause dark pigmented spots in the colon.  
✅ Medication effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis often has profound and easily recognizable findings on colonoscopy including edema, erythema, backwash ileitis, erosions, ulcerations, and loss of the typical vascular pattern. The dark mucosal pigmentation described in this patient’s colonoscopy is not indicative of ulcerative colitis.
